flashcards.title: a-while
flashcards.definition:
a period of time, especially a short one
It takes a while to recover from the operation.
in a while
Mr Thomas will be with you in a while.
for a while
At last, he could relax for a while.
a little/short while
Wait a little while before deciding.
We talked for quite a while (=a fairly long time) on the phone.
[)
flashcards.example:
A little while later, Rick returned with the drinks.
â€¢ After a while, I realised he was serious.
â€¢ After a while, I realized what he meant.
â€¢ It's been a while since I read the book, and I can't remember much about it, to be honest.
â€¢ It's been a while since we last heard from Jo.
â€¢ Can I hold her for a little while?
â€¢ How's Lynne? I haven't seen her for a while.
â€¢ He was furious, and it took him a while to calm down.

â€¢ 'Is that a photo of him?' 'Yeah, that was taken a while back - his hair's longer now.'
â€¢ He fought for the title a while ago.
â€¢ Can you wait a while?

flashcards.title: accommodation
flashcards.definition:
The word â€œaccommodationâ€ has several meanings depending on context:
1. Place to stay (most common in travel & daily use)
ğŸ‘‰ Meaning: a room, building, or place where someone can live, stay, or work.
We found cheap accommodation near the beach.
The hotel provides accommodation for 200 guests.
2. Adjustment or adaptation
ğŸ‘‰ Meaning: the process of adapting or adjusting to something.
The new policy is an accommodation to the needs of the workers.
3. Agreement or compromise
ğŸ‘‰ Meaning: an arrangement between people or groups to settle a disagreement.
The two sides reached an accommodation after long talks.
4. (Formal) Help or service
ğŸ‘‰ Meaning: something supplied to meet a need.
The airline gave free accommodation and meals to delayed passengers.
âœ… In daily English, when you hear accommodation, it usually refers to a place to stay (like a hotel, apartment, or guesthouse).
[english)

flashcards.title: acknowledge
flashcards.definition:
1- to admit or accept that something is true or that a situation exits.
2- recognize somethingâ€™s importance if people acknowledge something, they recognize how good or important it is
3- Accept somebodyâ€™s Authority to accept that someone or something has authority over people
4- to publicly announce that you are grateful for the help that someone has given you
5- to show someone that you have noticed them or heard what they have said
6- Say you have received something
[english)
flashcards.example:
he wish to acknowledged the support of the university

acknowledge
â€¢ The anniversary report is acknowledged as a tremendous achievement.
â€¢ In 1932 De Valera was elected as Prime Minister, and was acknowledged as leader of the Irish people.
â€¢ Callahan waved, acknowledging his fans.
â€¢ He acknowledges it's going to be a tough job, but he's going to try it anyway.
â€¢ I did a lot of work on that book. It annoys me that the editor never acknowledged it.
â€¢ We will never reform the justice system until we are prepared to acknowledge its fundamental defects.
â€¢ The paper never even acknowledged my letter or printed a correction.
â€¢ Please acknowledge receipt of this document by signing and returning the enclosed form.
â€¢ Cooke acknowledges receiving gifts that could be seen as bribes.
â€¢ In a correction that was published June 4,1995, the Globe acknowledged that Ayash did not sign the medication order.
â€¢ The committee acknowledges that mentally ill people in the community are not receiving the care and treatment they need.
â€¢ However, some acknowledge that the reforms had to be introduced quickly.
â€¢ The governor has acknowledged that there have been errors in his financial statements.
â€¢ I readily acknowledge that this is a very difficult request but I am afraid the timescale has to he met.
â€¢ The author wishes to acknowledge the assistance of the Defense Department.
â€¢ Zaire was forced to acknowledge the authority of the Congolese state.
â€¢ And, a base spokesman acknowledged the cooler ban did not prohibit knapsacks, soft-sided fabric coolers or wagons.
â€¢ Policy props up parental wishes and desires, but does it acknowledge the effect on the deaf child?
â€¢ In his speech he acknowledged the help his parents gave him at the start of his career.
â€¢ You have to acknowledge the truth of what she says.
â€¢ I have just sent off a letter acknowledging their message.
acknowledge that
â€¢ In particular, it is acknowledged that a de minimis level for warranties and indemnities will be included.
â€¢ Quite the contrary, it is acknowledged that carrying the message is all one can do.
â€¢ But he acknowledged that, for example, education could achieve the same objectives.
â€¢ It is now generally acknowledged that he was innocent.
â€¢ He acknowledged that it could prove up to four times more expensive than wind or wave power.
â€¢ She would accept students at the margins, but she acknowledged that she was engaging in a form of triage.
â€¢ The company has acknowledged that some incidents of harassment occurred, but denies allegations that it was widely tolerated.
â€¢ But Tisaby, while acknowledging that such witnesses exist, said it was unclear what they saw.
â€¢ We acknowledge that there have been dreadful mistakes and inexcusable mistreatment in the past, but we have learned from them.
â€¢ An industry spokesman acknowledged that toxic chemicals had been released into the river.
be widely/generally acknowledged to be something
â€¢ Another set of therapies which are generally acknowledged to be helpful are the physical ones which are mostly based around massage.
â€¢ Britain's clinical research is widely acknowledged to be in very bad shape.
â€¢ Making technical estimates of risk is widely acknowledged to be extremely tricky, with endless scope for disagreement amongst the experts.
â€¢ There, 50 or so textile mills produce what is widely acknowledged to be the finest wool cloth in the world.
acknowledge somebody as something
â€¢ The people acknowledged Mandela as their leader.
acknowledge receipt
â€¢ We would acknowledge receipt of Indictment 86-1246 and waive formal reading.
â€¢ We do not normally acknowledge receipt of letters for publication.
â€¢ Liverpool have acknowledged receipt of their letter in which they hold Saunders responsible for dangerous play.
â€¢ I should be grateful if you would acknowledge receipt of this letter.
â€¢ Please acknowledge receipt of this letter.
â€¢ The drafter can avoid such disputes by appropriate wording: We acknowledge receipt of your order and agree to supply you.
â€¢ He will acknowledge receipt of your reference within 5 working days.

flashcards.title: Adventure
flashcards.definition:
Noun: An unusual, exciting, or risky experience
Going hiking in the mountains was a real adventure.
A trip or journey full of new or unexpected events
They went on an adventure across Africa.
The act of trying something new and exciting
Starting a business is an adventure.
Verb (less common): To risk or dare to do something new or dangerous
He adventured into the forest alone.
ğŸ‘‰ In simple words: Adventure = an exciting or risky experience or journey.

flashcards.title: alien
flashcards.definition:
1 very different from what you are used to, especially in a way that is difficult to understand or accept SYN strange
the alien environment of the city
be alien to somebody
a way of life that is totally alien to us
2 belonging to another country or race SYN foreign
alien cultures
an alien multiracial society
3 [only before noun] relating to creatures from another world
alien beings from another planet
alien Noun
1 someone who is not a legal citizen of the country they are living or working in
illegal aliens entering the country
Register
Alien is used in official contexts. In everyday English, foreigner is used, but can sound disapproving or unfriendly. To avoid this, people often use the expression people from other countries instead:
In those days people from other countries rarely came to Japan.
2 in stories, a creature from another world

flashcards.title: apologize
flashcards.definition:
to tell someone that you are sorry that you have done something wrong
apologetic
Iâ€™m so sorry, I do apologize.
apologize to
I think you should apologize to your brother.
apologize for (doing) something
He later apologized for his behaviour.
I apologize for losing my temper.
Register
In everyday English, people often use the phrases say (you are) sorry or tell someone you are sorry, rather than apologize (to somebody):
I've already apologized to him.
Iâ€™ve already told him I'm sorry.
GRAMMAR: Patterns with apologize
â€¢ You apologize for something:
We would like to apologize for the delay.
â€¢ You apologize for doing something:
He apologized for being late.
â€¢ You apologize to someone:
We apologize to passengers for the delay.
âœ—Donâ€™t say: We apologize passengers for the delay.
[english)
flashcards.example:
apologize
â€¢ The editors admitted the mistake and apologized.
â€¢ Do not apologize as your weaknesses, failings and gaps in your c.v. are thrown at you.
â€¢ I don't know why I apologized, because I didn't do anything wrong.
â€¢ Has apologizing become a growth industry?
â€¢ David Kaczynski said nobody talked about or apologized for incidents like this.
â€¢ I must apologize for my son's behaviour -- he isn't usually this moody.
â€¢ She apologized for slowing him down and twice advised him to leave her.
â€¢ I apologize, it never takes this long.
â€¢ Fredrickson talked himself out and finally flushed and apologized like always and sat back down.
â€¢ She rushed into the hotel, apologizing profusely for being so late.
â€¢ The US has apologized to Britain for the accident that cost nine British lives.
â€¢ But all three young men apologize to Dawie.
â€¢ We apologize to everyone else who has the slightest complaint or modification regarding the first annual Tucson Musicians Register.
apologize for (doing) something
â€¢ She apologized for her earlier position.
â€¢ Sometimes she accused me; sometimes she apologized for herself.
â€¢ David Kaczynski said nobody talked about or apologized for incidents like this.
â€¢ They offer homemade cookies or jams or apologize for not having some ready.
â€¢ Perhaps unwisely, Clinton has apologized for raising taxes in 1993.

flashcards.title: appreciate
flashcards.definition:
1 [transitive] to understand how serious or important a situation or problem is or what someoneâ€™s feeling are SYN realize
appreciate the significance/importance/value of something
He did not fully appreciate the significance of signing the contract.
appreciate that
We appreciate that caring for children is an important job.
appreciate what/how/why
It is difficult to appreciate how bad the situation had become.
2 [transitive] used to thank someone in a polite way or to say that you are grateful for something they have done
Thanks ever so much for your help, I really appreciate it.
I appreciate your concern, but honestly, Iâ€™m fine.
Iâ€™d appreciate it if you let me get on with my job.
3 [transitive] to understand how good or useful someone or something is
Her abilities are not fully appreciated by her employer.
Iâ€™m not an expert, but I appreciate fine works of art.
4 [intransitive] technical to gradually become more valuable over a period of time OPP depreciate
Most investments are expected to appreciate at a steady rate.
Grammar Patterns with appreciate
â€¢ You say:
I appreciate your advice
I appreciate having your advice.
âœ—Donâ€™t say: I appreciate to have your advice.
Using the progressive
â€¢ Appreciate is not used in the progressive in meanings 1,2, and 3.
You say:
I appreciate what you are saying.
âœ—Donâ€™t say: I am appreciating what you are saying.
â€¢ Appreciate is used in the progressive in meaning 4:
The value of his work is still appreciating.

flashcards.title: arrange
flashcards.definition:
1 [intransitive, transitive] to organize or make plans for something such as a meeting, party, or trip
Contact your local branch to arrange an appointment.
Iâ€™d like to arrange a business loan.
arrange to do something
Have you arranged to meet Mark this weekend?
arrange something with somebody
Beth arranged a meeting with the marketing director.
arrange when/where/how etc
We still have to arrange how to get home.
arrange that
We had arranged that I would go for the weekend.
Matthew arrived at 2 o'clock as arranged.
2 [intransitive, transitive] to make it possible for someone to have or do something
arrange for something
The company will arrange for a taxi to meet you at the airport.
arrange for somebody to do something
Dave arranged for someone to drive him home.
3 [transitive] to put a group of things or people in a particular order or position
Ben arranged the flowers in a vase.
The list is arranged alphabetically.
arrange something in pairs/groups etc
The children were arranged in lines according to height.
4 [transitive] to write or change a piece of music so that it is suitable for a particular instrument
arrange something for something
a symphony arranged for the piano
[english)

flashcards.title: attendant
flashcards.definition:
1 someone whose job is to look after or help customer in a public place
a car park attendant
2 someone who looks after a very important person, for example a king or queen
Adj Attendant
relate to or caused by something
attendant problems / difficulties / dangers etc
nuclear power, with all its attendant risks
attendant on
Drugs are one of the issues attendant on running a school.
[english)
flashcards.example:
attendant
â€¢ The middle-aged sleeping-car attendant was dozing but dressed.
â€¢ My work as a flight attendant also proved valuable.
â€¢ Kim, 31, is a flight attendant for Delta Air Lines.
â€¢ He then gave them the choice of apologizing to the flight attendant or taking another flight.
â€¢ Londoner Richard Tompkins worked as a petrol pump attendant before starting the stamp company in 1956.
â€¢ Suddenly the pump attendant wanted nothing to do with this.
â€¢ a gas station attendant
â€¢ The petrol station attendant told her to apply for more at the Kommandatur which turned out to be the old town hall.
â€¢ Disheartened, Santa Anna separated from his large escort and planned to slip through the mountainous country with three attendants.


attendant

â€¢ a prince and his attendant servants

â€¢ And it does have its attendant problems which it is only sensible to recognise.

audience of

2 [countable also + plural verb] British English the people who watch or listen to a particular programme, or who see or hear a particular artistâ€™s, writerâ€™s etc work
The show attracts a regular audience of about 20 million.
target audience (=the type of people that a programme, advertisement etc is supposed to attract)
Goya was one of the first painters to look for a wider audience for his work.

3 [countable] a formal meeting with a very important person
audience with

flashcards.title: aware
flashcards.definition:
1 if you are aware that a situation exists, you realize or know that it exists
aware of
The children are aware of the danger of taking drugs.
Mr Braley has been made aware of the need for absolute secrecy.
aware that
Were you aware that Joe had this problem with his knee?
well/fully/acutely aware
They were well aware that the company was losing money.
As you are aware, a fee will be charged annually.
2 if you are aware of something, you notice it, especially because you can see, hear, feel, or smell it
aware of
She was aware of a tall dark figure watching her.
He was aware of the wind in his face.
aware that
Bill became aware that he was still holding his glass.
3 understanding a lot about what is happening around you and paying attention to it, especially because you realize possible dangers and problems
politically/socially/environmentally etc aware
the socially aware novels of Dickens
We should promote environmentally aware and responsible science.
4 so/as far as I am aware

flashcards.title: Baggage
flashcards.definition:
ext:
1. Main Meaning (Suitcases & Travel)Baggage = the bags, suitcases, and personal belongings that a traveler carries.âœ… Example: The airline lost my baggage at the airport.(Same meaning as luggage.)
2. Emotional / Figurative MeaningBaggage can also mean emotional problems, experiences, or responsibilities from the past that affect someone now.âœ… Example: He has a lot of emotional baggage from his childhood.
3. Informal (Negative about a person)Sometimes used (often impolitely) to refer to a troublesome or unwanted person.âœ… Example: Some people considered her just old baggage.
âš¡ Tip:
Baggage = more common in American English.
Luggage = more common in British English.

flashcards.title: bargain
flashcards.definition:
1 something you buy cheaply or for less than its usual price
There are no bargains in the clothes shops at the moment.
Itâ€™s an attractive little home, and I think itâ€™s a bargain.
That second-hand table was a real bargain.
Good watches don't come at bargain prices.
Bargain hunters (=people looking for things to buy at low prices) queued outside the store for hours.
2 an agreement, made between two people or groups, to do something in return for something else
make/strike a bargain
Management and unions have struck a bargain over wage increases.
Iâ€™ve kept my side of the bargain and I expect you to keep yours.
drive strike a hard bargain
3 into the bargain into the bargain
Bargain Noun
to discuss the conditions of a sale, agreement etc, for example to try and get a lower price
bargain for
workers bargaining for better pay
bargain over
They bargained over the level of wages.
bargain with
women bargaining with traders
[english)
flashcards.example:
COLLOCATIONSADJECTIVES
a real bargain
In the market you can sometimes pick up a real bargain.

an absolute bargain
Â£59.99 is an absolute bargain.

a brilliant/amazing bargain
The house they bought was an amazing bargain.

VERBS
look for/search for a bargain
She began looking for bargains at car boot sales.

get a bargain
Everyone likes to think they are getting a bargain.

find a bargain
Investors may be able to find some bargains this year.

pick up/snap up a bargain (=find one)
You can often pick up a bargain at an auction.

offer a bargain
The Regency hotel is offering off-season bargains.
BARGAIN + NOUN

a bargain price
In the sales you can get a fully fitted kitchen at a bargain price.

a bargain buy
This remains a bargain buy at Â£3.99.

a bargain hunter (=someone looking for a bargain)
Bargain hunters queued for hours before the store opened.
bargain hunting
They're off to do some bargain hunting at the January sales.
a bargain basement (=part of a large shop below ground where the price of goods is reduced)
Everything is reduced to clear in the bargain basement!

flashcards.title: beat
flashcards.definition:
The word â€œbeatâ€ has several meanings depending on the context. Here are the most common ones:
âœ… As a verb (action word):To win against someone in a competition or game:
Example: She beat him at chess.
(Meaning: She won.)
To hit repeatedly:
Example: The man was beating the drum.
(Meaning: Hitting the drum again and again.)
To mix quickly (especially in cooking):
Example: Beat the eggs until smooth.
(Meaning: Stir or whip fast.)
To be very tired (informal, US):
Example: Iâ€™m totally beat after work.
(Meaning: Very tired.)
âœ… As a noun:A regular rhythm (in music):
Example: I love the beat of this song.
An area that a police officer patrols:
Example: He walks his beat every night.
[english)
flashcards.example:
beat
â€¢ Lewis was a tough boxer, and a hard man to beat.
â€¢ Hey, it beats a bake sale.
â€¢ Back then, girls were told that they could never beat a boy at tennis.
â€¢ Jake's home-made burgers beat anything you can get at fast-food restaurants.
â€¢ Whatever Messrs Mondale, Foot and Kinnock said about raising taxes in the 1980s, they were going to be beaten anyway.
â€¢ It's not a particularly good job, but it certainly beats being unemployed.
â€¢ It was clear that she had been badly beaten by her husband.
â€¢ My Father used to let me beat him at chess.
â€¢ Following the incident with the boy a Dig Daddy style man had gone to his door and beaten him up.
â€¢ But UMass still won on the road against a team that should have beaten it.
â€¢ He used to come home drunk and beat my mother.
â€¢ Children were beating on different kinds of drums.
â€¢ On the ultrasound machine, I could see the baby's heart beating strongly.
â€¢ Teachers are no longer allowed to beat students who misbehave.
â€¢ Beat the cream into the fruit puree, pour into bowls, and chill.
â€¢ Beat the eggs and pour in the milk.
â€¢ Carry on beating the eggs with a fork until they're light and fluffy.
â€¢ Do you think the Socialists will beat the Liberals in the election?
â€¢ Osborne wanted to beat the living daylights out of Flanagan.
â€¢ No one has figured out how to beat the problem of rodents eating the crops.
â€¢ My torso and my wrists felt as though Edna had beaten them with sticks.
â€¢ In a separate bowl, beat together the oil and flour.
â€¢ Slaves were sometimes beaten with sticks or even whipped.

2
beaten to death
â€¢ A Chancellor of the Exchequer who had failed to prevent thieves penetrating his treasury was summarily beaten to death.
â€¢ And when he himself was nearly beaten to death.
â€¢ Her body will be covered with bruises, as if she had been beaten to death.
â€¢ Recalcitrants were chained, starved and beaten to death.
â€¢ In Westport, a 3-year-old boy was beaten to death after wetting his pants, authorities allege.
â€¢ Apparently, he was beaten to death and, as a result, swore that he would for ever haunt the local area.
â€¢ In the minutes that followed, McDuffie was beaten to death by a group of Dade County police officers.
3
beat on/against/at etc
â€¢ This type of groove should be played very tight, smack on the beat at all times, but with a little bounce.
â€¢ With an electric mixer, beat at low speed until moistened and then at medium speed for 3 minutes.
â€¢ Blend at lowest speed 30 seconds and then beat at medium speed 3 minutes.
â€¢ The rain beat against my face, pasted my hair to my scalp, ran down my neck.
â€¢ Recovering, Emmie seized the thin old hearthrug and began to beat at the flames.
â€¢ When the sun is at its highest, it beats on the wall.
â€¢ A young man was beaten on two occasions but never arrested for anything.
4
you canâ€™t beat something (for something)
â€¢ For romance, you can't beat the Rainbow Lodge.
5
beat... to it
â€¢ Book now before you're beaten to it!
â€¢ Bridget had only just beaten her to it.
â€¢ Gloria had beaten me to it.
â€¢ Martin learnt later that another team had beaten him to it.
â€¢ The Aldam family from Guildford have beaten them to it.
â€¢ Gary had beaten them to it, and had demanded contributions for the mission.
â€¢ He'd beaten Danny Crompton to it that time.

flashcards.title: bother
flashcards.definition:
1 MAKE AN EFFORT [intransitive, transitivec usually in questions and negatives] to make the effort to do something
(not) bother to do something
He didnâ€™t bother to answer the question.
not bother about/with
He didnâ€™t bother with a reply.
(not) bother doing something Many young people didnâ€™t bother voting.
donâ€™t/didnâ€™t/wonâ€™t etc bother
â€˜Do you want me to wait for you?â€™ â€˜No, donâ€™t bother.â€™
Why bother to go abroad, when there are so many nice places here?
2 WORRY [intransitive, transitive]
to make someone feel slightly worry, upset, or concern
Being in a crowd really bothers me.
It was very noisy, but that didnâ€™t bother me.
bother about
I try not to bother about what other people think.
it bothers somebody that/how/when
It really bothered me that heâ€™d forgotten my birthday.
3 ANNOY [intransitive, transitive]
to annoy someone, especially by interrupt them when they are trying to do something
Danny, donâ€™t bother Ellen while sheâ€™s reading.
Would it bother you if I put on some music?
bother somebody about/with something
It didnâ€™t seem worth bothering the doctor about.
4 somebody can t couldn t be bothered to do something somebody can t couldn t be bothered to do something
5 CAUSE PAIN [transitive] if a part of your body bother you, it is slightly painful or uncomfortable
My backâ€™s been bothering me.
6 sorry to bother you sorry to bother you
7 FRIGHTEN [transitive] to upset or frighten someone by talking to them when they do not want to talk to you, trying to hurt them, touch them sexually etc
Donâ€™t worry â€“ my dog wonâ€™t bother you.
If he starts bothering you, let me know.
8 not bother yourself not bother your head not bother yourself not bother your head
to not spend time or effort on something, either because it is not important or because it is too difficult
Cliff didnâ€™t want to bother himself with details.
9 bother it them etc bother it them etc
used to express a sudden feeling of annoyance about something
Oh bother it! The threadâ€™s broken again!
[english)
flashcards.example:
Just because you live alone does not mean that you should not bother.

â€¢ Something's bothering him but I'm not sure what.
â€¢ You know the story by heart.-Then why did you bother in the first place?
â€¢ Will you stop bothering me? I'm trying to watch a program.
â€¢ The only thing that bothers me is how I'm going to get from the station to the farm.
â€¢ What bothers me is that you didn't feel you could talk to me or your father about it.

â€¢ Irate customers who bother to complain to their local water executives will be told the rises are no higher than were forecast.
â€¢ You don't hand your homework in on time, or you don't even bother to do it.
â€¢ I have challenged the prospective Labour candidate in Harrow, West to do so, but he has not bothered to reply.
â€¢ Sorry to bother you, but could you help me one more time with the copier?
â€¢ Will it bother you if I play some music?
â€¢ "Why didn't you ask me for help?" "I didn't want to bother you."
â€¢ You shouldn't let little things like that bother you.
â€¢ Excuse me, Miss, is that man bothering you?

flashcards.title: bring
flashcards.definition:
1
a) to take something or someone with you to the place where you are now, or to the place you are talking about take
Did you bring an umbrella?
It was the first time Joey had ever brought a girl home.
They brought news of further fighting along the border.
bring somebody/something to somebody/something
Is it OK if I bring some friends to the party?
bring somebody/something with you
For some reason, Jesse had brought a tape recorder with him.
b) to get something for someone and take it to them
bring somebody something
Can you bring me another beer?
Robert asked the waiter to bring him the check.
While she was in prison, friends used to bring her books.
bring somebody/something to somebody/something
He expects me to bring everything to him.
2
a) to make a particular situation exist, or cause a particular feeling efforts to bring peace to the region
The strikes are expected to bring chaos.
The senatorâ€™s speech brought an angry response from civil rights groups.
b) to cause someone or something to reach a particular state or condition
bring something to an end / close / halt / conclusion
(=make something stop)
The trial was swiftly brought to an end.
It was the war that first brought him to power
(=made him have power over a country).
So far the US has been unable to bring him to justice
(=make him be punished for his actions).
Bring the sauce to the boil (=heat it until it boils).
The country had been brought to its knees
(=caused to be in such a bad condition that it is almost impossible to continue).
3 [always + adverb / preposition] to make something move in a particular direction
bring something up/down/round etc Bring your arm up slowly until itâ€™s level with your shoulder.
The storm brought the old oak tree crashing down.
4 [always + adverb / preposition]
if something brings people to a place, it makes them go there
The discovery of gold brought thousands of people to the Transvaal.
what brings you here?
(=used to ask why someone is in a particular place)
What brings you here on a night like this?
5 to make something available for people to use, have, enjoy etc The expansion of state education brought new and wider opportunities for working class children.
bring something to somebody/something
The government is launching a new initiative to bring jobs to deprived areas.
bring somebody something
Itâ€™s a good sign â€“ letâ€™s hope it will bring us some luck.
6 if a period of time brings a particular event or situation, the event or situation happens during that time
The 1930s brought unemployment and economic recession.
Who knows what the future will bring?
7 bring charges a lawsuit a court case a prosecution a claim against somebody bring charges a lawsuit a court case a prosecution a claim against somebody
8 bring a smile to somebody s lips face bring a smile to somebody s lips face
9 bring tears to somebody s eyes bring tears to somebody s eyes
10 bring the total number score etc to something bring the total number score etc to something
11 cannot could not bring yourself to do something cannot could not bring yourself to do something
12 spoken used when saying that something is the next thing that you want to talk about
that/this/which brings me to...
This brings me to the main point of todayâ€™s meeting.
13 if a programme is brought to you by a particular television or radio company, they broadcast it or make it
something is brought to you by somebody
This programme is brought to you by the BBC.
14 bring something to bear on upon something bring something to bear on upon something
to use something, for example your power, authority, or your knowledge, in a way that will have a big effect on something or someone
The full force of the law was brought to bear on anyone who criticized the government.
15 bring home the bacon bring home the bacon
[english)

flashcards.title: buffer-day
flashcards.definition: A buffer day is a strategically planned day (or time block) used to handle unexpected tasks, administrative work, or to decompress between demanding periods like vacations or major projects, preventing overwhelm and ensuring focus on high-priority work later. It acts as flexible margin, clearing messes, resetting routines (unpacking, groceries), managing emails, and allowing for essential prep, ensuring subsequent 'Focus Days' are truly productive and 'Free Days' are truly restful.

1 GROUP OF THINGS [countable] a group of things that are fastened, held, or growing together
bunch of
Iâ€™ll send her a bunch of flowers.
He had a bunch of keys on his belt.
a bunch of grapes
2 GROUP OF PEOPLE [singular] informal a group of people
The ancient Egyptians were a clever bunch.
bunch of
a friendly bunch of people
3 the best/pick of the bunch
the best among a group of people or things
4 LARGE AMOUNT [singular] American English informal a large number of people or things, or a large amount of something
bunch of
Thereâ€™s a whole bunch of places I want to visit.
5 bunches
thanks a bunch1
COLLOCATIONS
PHRASES
a bunch of flowers/roses/daffodils etc
I picked a bunch of flowers from the garden.
a bunch of keys
A bunch of keys dangled from his belt.
a bunch of grapes
She served the cheese with a bunch of black grapes.
a bunch of bananas
Bunches of bananas hung in the trees.
a bunch of herbs/parsley/thyme etc
You might like to add a bunch of fresh herbs to the stock.
Bunch noun
1 [intransitive, transitive] to stay close together in a group, or to make people do this
The children bunched together in small groups.
John stopped, forcing the rest of the group to bunch up behind him.
2 [intransitive, transitive] to make part of your body tight, or to become tight like this
Sean bunched his fists.
3 [intransitive, transitive] to pull material together tightly in folds
She bunched the cloth up and threw it away.
4 [transitive] to hold or tie things together in a bunch
[english)

â€¢ Is there a connection between Jack Benny and Charles Manson, by any chance?
â€¢ Can anyone out there tell me what frequency Radio 5 broadcasts on... by any chance on shortwave?

flashcards.definition:
A cardigan is a type of knitted sweater that opens at the front.It may have buttons or a zip, or sometimes no fastener at all.
Example:She wore a red cardigan over her dress.
I love wearing cardigans in the fall.
Cardigans can be worn by men or women and are often made of wool or cotton.

flashcards.title: caught
flashcards.definition:
the past tense and past participle of catch
1- Take and hold
a) to get hold of and stop an object such as a ball that is moving through the air
b) to suddenly take hold of something or someone whit your hand
2-find\stop somebody
a) to stop someone after you have been chase them and not let them get away
b) to find a criminal or enemy and stop them from escape
3- see someone doing something
to see someone doing something that they did not want you to know they were doing
4-ILLNESS to get an infectious disease
7- ANIMAL/FISH to trap an animal or fish by using a trap, net, or hook, or by hunt it
9- NOT MISS SOMEBODY / SOMETHING to not be too late to do something, see something, talk to someone etc OPP miss
10- GET STUCK if your hand, finger, clothing etc catches or is caught in something, it gets stuck in it accidentally
11- HEAR [transitive] to manage to hear a sound
12- do\see something to go somewhere in
order to do or see something
13- BURN
a) catch fire if something catches fire, it starts to burn accidentally
b) if a fire catches, it starts to burn
25- HIT [transitive] to hit someone in or on a particular part of their body
28- CONTAINER if a container catches liquid, it is in a position where the liquid falls into it

flashcards.title: cell
flashcards.definition:
1 BODY the smallest part of a living thing that can exist independently
blood/brain/nerve cell
red blood cells
cancer cells
Embryos grow by cell division (=the splitting of cells).
2 PRISON a small room in a prison or police station where prisoners are kept
He spent a night in the cells at the local police station.
the walls of his prison cell
3 PHONE American English a cellular phone; a telephone that you can carry around with you, that works by using a network of radio stations to pass on signals SYN mobile British English
Call me on my cell if youâ€™re running late.
4 ELECTRIC a piece of equipment for producing electricity from chemicals, heat, or light
a car powered by electric fuel cells
5 SECRET GROUP a small group of people who are working secretly as part of a larger political organization
a terrorist cell
6 RELIGIOUS a small room in a monastery or convent where someone sleeps
7 INSECT/SMALL ANIMAL a small space that an insect or other small creature has made to live in or use
the cells of a honeycomb
COLLOCATIONS
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + CELL
a blood/nerve/brain/muscle etc cell
No new brain cells are produced after birth.
a human/animal/plant cell
the structure of plant cells
a red cell (=the most common type of blood cell)
The red cells carry the oxygen.
a white cell (=a type of blood cell that defends your body against disease)
In leukaemia there is an abnormal and excessive formation of white cells.
a living/dead cell
Every living cell has a nucleus.
normal/abnormal
The test enables doctors to detect abnormal cells.
a stem cell (=one that divides and repairs the body, and may be used in medical treatment)
Stem cells may make life-saving treatment possible.
a cancer cell
Already there are many treatments which destroy cancer cells.
VERBS
a cell divides
White blood cells divide rapidly.
CELL + NOUN
cell division
The embryo grows by cell division.
a cell count (=the number of cells in a particular amount of blood)
A healthy person' s red cell count is close to 1,000
[english)

flashcards.title: chain
flashcards.definition:
Chain Noun
1 JOINED RINGS [countable, uncountable] a series of metal ring which are join together in a line and used for fasten things, supporting weight, decoration etc link
She had a gold chain around her neck.
a length of heavy chain the mayorâ€™s chain of office
(=a decoration worn by some British officials at ceremonies)
pull the chain
British English (=flush the toilet)
a bicycle chain (=that makes the wheels turn),
jewellery
2 CONNECTED EVENTS [countable] a connect series of events or actions, especially which lead to a final result
the chain of events that led to World War I
The salesmen are just one link in the chain (=part of a process) of distribution.
a rather complicated chain of reasoning
chain of command chain of command food chain food chain
3 SHOPS/HOTELS [countable] a number of shop, hotel, cinema etc owned or manage by the same company or person
chain of a chain of restaurants
hotel/restaurant/retail etc chain
several major UK supermarket chains chain store chain store
4 CONNECTED LINE [countable] people or things which are connected or next to each other forming a line
mountain/island chain
the Andean mountain chain
chain of atoms/molecules etc technical
a chain of amino acids
They formed a human chain (=a line of people who pass things from one person to the next) to move the equipment.
daisy chains (=flowers tied together)
5 PRISONERS [countable usually plural] metal chain fastened to the leg and arms of a prisoner, to prevent them from escape
in chains
He was led away in chains.
ball and chain
(=a chain attached to someoneâ€™s ankle at one end with a heavy metal ball at the other)
6 BUYING A HOUSE [countable usually singular] British English a number of people buying houses, where each person must complete the sale of their own house before they can buy the next personâ€™s house
Verb Chain
[transitive]
to fasten someone or something to something else using a chain, especially in order to prevent them from escaping or being steal
chain somebody/something to something
a bicycle chained to the fence
Four activists chained themselves to the gates.
chain somebody/something up
The elephants were chained up by their legs.
chain somebody/something together
Their hands and feet were chained together.
2 be chained to something be chained to something
[english)

flashcards.title: chase
flashcards.definition:
1 FOLLOW [intransitive, transitive] to quickly follow someone or something in order to catch them
The dogs saw him running and chased him.
kids chasing around the house
chase somebody along/down/up something etc
The police chased the suspect along Severn Avenue.
chase after
A gang of boys chased after her, calling her names.
â–º see thesaurus at follow
2 MAKE SOMEBODY/SOMETHING LEAVE [transitive always + adverb/preposition]
to make someone or something leave, especially by following them for a short distance and threatening them
chase somebody away/off
The men were chased off by troops, who fired warning shots.
chase somebody out of something
Anne went to chase the dog out of the garden.
3 TRY TO GET SOMETHING [intransitive, transitive]
to use a lot of time and effort trying to get something such as work or money
Top graduates from the university are chased by major companies.
chase after
reporters chasing after a story
4 HURRY [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] British English to rush or hurry somewhere
chase around/up/down etc
I was chasing around getting everything organized.
5 ROMANCE [transitive] to try hard to make someone notice you and pay attention to you, because you want to have a romantic relationship with them
â€˜Sometimes a girl wants to be chased, â€™ Amelia said.
6 METAL [transitive] technical to decorate metal with a special tool
chased silver
7 chase the dragon
chase somebody/something â†” down
chase somebody/something â†” up
Chase Noun
1 [countable] the act of following someone or something quickly in order to catch them a high-speed
car chase
Police spotted the car and gave chase (=chased it).
2 [singular] when you use a lot of time and effort trying to get something
chase after
the chase after higher-paying jobs

flashcards.title: colleague
flashcards.definition:
someone you work with â€“ used especially by professional people SYN co-worker
Today, colleague is used more often in professional contexts, sometimes referring to people who work in the same field but not for the same institution, whereas coworker tends to be used for people who share a workspace or duties.
[english)
flashcards.example:
colleague
someone who you work with in a company or organization, for example someone working in the same office, or someone teaching in the same school

Friends and former colleagues described him as a kind and caring man.
She discovered that her male colleagues were earning more than she was.
workmate British English someone who you work with. Workmate is more informal than colleague

He went out for a drink with his workmates.

coworker American English someone who you work with

I was sad to say goodbye to all of my coworkers.

associate someone who you work with, especially another businessman or businesswoman

They are close friends and business associates.
staff all the people who work for an organization

The company employs a total of 520 staff.
a staff meeting

flashcards.title: come-over
flashcards.definition:
1
a) if someone comes over, they visit you at your house
Do you want to come over on Friday evening?
b) if someone comes over, they come to the country where you are
to/from
When did your family first come over to America?
2 come over somebody if a strong feeling comes over you, you suddenly experience it
A wave of sleepiness came over me.
Iâ€™m sorry about that â€“ I donâ€™t know what came over me (=I do not know why I behaved in that way).
3 if an idea comes over well, people can understand it easily
I thought that the points he was making came over quite clearly.
4 if someone comes over in a particular way, they seem to have particular qualities SYN come across
He didnâ€™t come over very well (=seem to have good qualities) in the interview.
as
She comes over as a very efficient businesswoman.
5 come over (all) shy/nervous etc informal to suddenly become very shy, nervous etc
[)

come to/from
â€¢ I came over to give him a hug and noticed a cigarette still burning in the ashtray on the desk.
â€¢ Numbers of his opponents had been captured or come over to him.
â€¢ He came over to my apartment only once.
â€¢ Lord Henry came over to tell Dorian that the man was dead.
â€¢ The kids keep calling for Tfo Vic to come over to the lunch table they are not allowed to leave.
â€¢ People were coming over to us out of shops, pleading to be included in my trials.
â€¢ Pipkin, who looked round for Hazel and then came over to wait beside him.
come as

â€¢ Alfred Molina's Shannon comes over as an assemblage of mannerisms rather than a man whose behaviour arises from dissipation and anguish.
â€¢ The play comes over as both an astute social comedy and a door-slamming farce.

flashcards.title: complaint
flashcards.definition:
1 [countable, uncountable] a statement in which someone complains about something
If you wish to make a complaint, you should see the manager.
The sales assistants are trained to deal with customer complaints in a friendly manner.
complaint about
Keating was dismissed after complaints about the quality of his work.
complaint of
complaints of police brutality
complaint from/to
complaints from local residents
a complaint to the Advertising Standards Authority
complaint against
All complaints against police officers are carefully investigated.
complaint that
We are concerned by complaints that children are being bullied.
2 [countable] something that you complain about
Our main complaint was the poor standard of service.
My only complaint is that the price is rather high.
3 [countable] formal an illness that affects a particular part of your body
He is having treatment for a chest complaint.

flashcards.title: convenient
flashcards.definition:
1 useful to you because it save you time, or doe not spoil your plan or cause you problems OPP inconvenient
convenient for

convenient to do something

Register

flashcards.title: cross
flashcards.definition:
verb Cross
1- to go or stretch from one side of something such as a road room etc to the other
2- CROSS A LINE ETC if you cross, a line, track etc, you go over and beyond it
3- tow roads \lines etc if tow or more roads, lines, etc cross, or if one crosses another, they across each other
4- Legs \ arms \ ankles if you cross your legs arms or ankles you put one on top of the other
5- BREED OF PLANT/ANIMAL [transitive] to mix two or more different breed of animal or plant to form a new breed
6- MAKE SOMEBODY ANGRY [transitive] to make someone angry by oppose their plans or orders
7- SPORT [intransitive, transitive] to kick, throw, or hit the ball across the playing area in a sport such as football, hockey etc
8- CHEQUE [transitive] British English to draw two lines across a cheque to show that it must be paid into the bank account of the person whose name is on it

9- LETTERS [intransitive] if two letters about the same subject cross in the post, each was sent before the other was received
noun cross
1- Mixture of thing
2- Mark on paper
3- CHRISTIAN SIGN
4- PUNISHMENT an upright post of wood with another crossing it near the top, that people in the past were fasten to with nail and left to die on as a punishment
5- MILITARY AWARD a decoration in the shape of a cross that is given to someone as an honour, especially for military courage
6- SPORT
a) a kick or hit of the ball in a sport such as football, hockey etc, that goes across the field
b) a way of hitting someone in the sport of boxing, in which your arm goes over theirs as they try to hit you
7- PROBLEM if you describe something as the cross that someone has to bear, you mean it is a problem that makes them very unhappy or worried, and that continues for a long time
adj cross
angry or annoy
Prefix Cross
1 going from one side to the other

flashcards.title: Cruise
flashcards.definition:
Cruise (verb & noun)As a verb:
To travel smoothly at a steady speed, usually in a car, ship, or plane.
We cruised down the highway at 80 km/h.
The ship is cruising in the Caribbean.
To move around without any particular goal, often for pleasure.
They spent the evening cruising around town.
(Informal) To move easily or without effort.
The team cruised to victory. (meaning: won easily)
As a noun:
A holiday or trip on a ship.
Weâ€™re going on a cruise to the Bahamas.
A smooth ride or journey.
The plane had a comfortable cruise.

1- a cloth bag filled with soft material that you put on a chair or the floor to make it more comfortable
2- something that stops one thing from hitting another thing
3- something, especially money, that prevents you from being immediately affected by a bad situation
4- the soft rubber edge of the table used for playing billiards or snooker
Verb
1- to make the effect of a fall or hit less painful, for example by having something soft in the way
2- to protected someone from an unpleasant situation or the unpleasant effects of something

2- good sports shoes should provide a cushion when running

2 money that you pay when you rent something such as an apartment or car, which will be given back if you do not damage it

5 an amount or layer of a substance that gradually develops in a particular place
fatty deposits on the heart

lose your deposit (=not get enough votes)

flashcards.title: drain
flashcards.definition:
1 LIQUID
a) [transitive] to make the water or liquid in something flow away
The swimming pool is drained and cleaned every winter.
drain something from something
Brad drained all the oil from the engine.
Can you drain the spaghetti, please (=pour away the water from the pan)?
b) [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] if liquid drains away, it flows away
drain away/off/from
I watched the bath water drain away.
c) [intransitive] if something drains, the liquid that is in it or on it flows away and it becomes dry
Open ditches drain very efficiently.
She washed up and left the dishes to drain.
well-drained/poorly-drained soil (=soil from which water flows away quickly or slowly)
This plant needs rich, well-drained soil.
2 MAKE SOMEBODY TIRED [transitive] to make someone feel very tired and without any energy
Working with children all day really drains you.
3 USE TOO MUCH [transitive] to use too much of something, especially money, so that there is not enough left
Huge imports were draining the countryâ€™s currency reserves.
4 the colour/blood drains from somebodyâ€™s face/cheeks
5 drain a glass/cup etc
drain away
drain something â†” off
See Verb table
noun drain
1 especially British English a pipe that carries water or waste liquids away
The flood was caused by a blocked drain.
Thereâ€™s a problem with the drains.
2 British English the frame of metal bars over a drain where water etc can flow into it SYN grate American English
3 American English the hole in the bottom of a bath or sink that water flows out through SYN plughole British English
4 a drain on something
5 down the drain

flashcards.title: drown
flashcards.definition:
1 [intransitive, transitive] to die from being under water for too long, or to kill someone in this way
Many people drowned when the boat overturned.
Jane was drowned in the river.
drown yourself
Depressed, Peter tried to drown himself.
2 (also drown out) [transitive] if a loud noise drowns out another sound, it prevents it from being heard
A train blew its whistle and drowned his voice.
The noise of the battle was drowned out by his aircraftâ€™s engine.
3 [transitive] to cover something, especially food, with more liquid than is necessary or nice
drown something in something
The fish was drowned in a rich sauce.
4 [intransitive, transitive] to have a very strong feeling or a serious problem that is difficult to deal with
drown in
Relief agencies are drowning in frustration.
The country is drowning in debt.
5 drown your sorrows

flashcards.title: Entertainment vs Amusement vs Diversion
flashcards.definition:
"Amusement" refers to a feeling of lighthearted pleasure or enjoyment that is derived from something, typically a form of entertainment. It can refer to an activity or event that is intended to bring a smile to someone's face or to make them laugh.
"Entertainment" refers to an activity or event, such as a play, movie, concert, or sporting event, that is designed to provide enjoyment, interest, or pleasure to an audience. It can also refer to any form of media or art, such as a book or television show, that is meant to be consumed for enjoyment.
"Diversion" refers to an activity or event that serves to distract or take one's mind off of something, especially something that may be stressful or boring. It can also refer to the act of redirecting something, such as water or traffic, to a different course or direction.
In general, all three terms refer to activities or events that are intended to provide enjoyment, interest, or pleasure, but they differ in their specific connotations and the ways in which they are used.

flashcards.title: entrance
flashcards.definition:
1 [countable] a door, gate etc that you go through to enter a place OPP exit
entrance to/of
the main entrance to the school
front/back/side entrance
the station entrance
entrance hall/foyer/gate etc
2 [countable usually singular] the act of entering a place or room, especially in a way that people notice
Bridget made a dramatic entrance into the room.
3 [uncountable] the right or ability to go into a place
entrance to
Entrance to the museum is free.
Reporters even managed to gain entrance to her hotel.
How much is the entrance fee (=money you pay to get in somewhere)?
4 [uncountable] permission to become a member of or become involved in a profession, university, society etc
the initial interview for entrance to the Civil Service
entrance examinations
5 [countable] when a person, country, organization etc first becomes involved in a particular area of activity
entrance into

flashcards.title: Escape
flashcards.definition:
The word â€œescapeâ€ means to get away from a place, person, or situation, usually because it is dangerous, unpleasant, or you donâ€™t want to be there.
Meanings of escape
As a verb:
To get free from something
The prisoner escaped from jail.
(meaning: he got away from prison)
To avoid something bad
She narrowly escaped an accident.
(meaning: she avoided it)
To leak out or get away
Gas escaped from the pipe.
(meaning: it leaked out)
As a noun:
An act of getting away
His escape from prison was on the news.
(meaning: the action of leaving)
A way to forget problems
Reading novels is her escape from stress.
(meaning: relief from reality)
âœ… Simple synonym examples: get away, break free, avoid, exit.

flashcards.title: Exhausted
flashcards.definition:
1- extremely tire
Register: In everyday English, people often say worn out rather than exhausted:
You look worn out.
2- having or containing no more of a particular thing or substance
[english)
flashcards.example:
exhausted
â€¢ Sometimes it flops to the ground as if exhausted.
â€¢ Sufficient space is available for lexicographers to create an extra four thousand entry-versions per table before the available space is 

exhausted.
â€¢ The oxygen supply would soon become exhausted.
â€¢ We had been walking for over 20 miles, and we were completely exhausted.
â€¢ But the plot fertility would become exhausted and crops would be poorer.
â€¢ The exhausted dancers collapsed as they stepped off the stage.
â€¢ I was exhausted every day when I first started teaching, but I'm used to it now.
â€¢ The five of them were still exhausted from their 36-hour train ride.
â€¢ All that's left are some barren hillsides and a couple of exhausted mines.
â€¢ Diminished responsibility did not mean exhausted responsibility, said Lord Taylor.
â€¢ After two days they found him, an exhausted scarecrow of a figure hardly able to stand.
â€¢ In time, people wore themselves out and peace, of an exhausted sort, was restored.
â€¢ And what sort of pressure could an exhausted waitress apply?
exhausted from/by
â€¢ I hear his words but am too exhausted by guilt and remorse to answer.
â€¢ A text would entail its interpretation only if meaning was exhausted by sense, the coded or literal meanings studied by semantics.
â€¢ Johnson complained of having been rendered exhausted by Sir Alexander's over-zealous efforts to entertain him.
â€¢ Ron was exhausted from studying all night.
â€¢ They lay side by side on the couch, until she fell asleep, exhausted by the emotions of the day.
â€¢ The poor man was exhausted by the end of the performance and his cardigan looked like a sack!
â€¢ They looked exhausted by the march.
â€¢ Nice and comfortable and dull. Exhausted by their exercise, they were content to drowse in the sun.
â€¢ The motives were plentiful-fed up, afraid, exhausted by unhappiness.

flashcards.title: exposure
flashcards.definition:
1. Being in contact with something (often harmful):
Exposure means coming into contact with something, especially something dangerous or unpleasant.
â€¢ Example:
Prolonged exposure to the sun can cause skin damage.
(= Being in the sun too long can harm your skin.)
2. Revealing or uncovering something hidden:
It can also mean showing or revealing something that was hidden or secret.
â€¢ Example:
The journalist's report led to the exposure of government corruption.
(= The corruption was revealed.)
3. Public attention or visibility:
It can refer to being seen or noticed by the public or media.
â€¢ Example:
The new artist gained a lot of exposure after the TV interview.
(= Many people saw or heard about the artist.)
4. Photography â€“ amount of light received:
In photography, exposure means how much light hits the camera sensor or film.
â€¢ Example:
This photo is too darkâ€”it needs more exposure.

flashcards.title: express
flashcards.definition:
S2 W1 verb [transitive]
FEELING to tell or show what you are feeling or thinking by using words, looks, or actions
express your views/opinions Billâ€™s not afraid to express his opinions.
Parents have expressed their concerns about their childrenâ€™s safety.
She expressed an interest in seeing York.
express something in/by/through something
Express your reasons for applying in simple terms.
express sympathy/fear/anger etc
She doesnâ€™t express her emotions as much as he does.
express thanks/gratitude (for something) (to somebody) (=thank someone in a speech or by writing a letter)
Finally, Iâ€™d like to express my sincere thanks to all those who have helped today.
express doubts/reservations
The USA expressed reservations before agreeing to sign the agreement.
Many people have expressed their opposition to the proposals.
express yourself (=say what you think or feel) Young children often have difficulty expressing themselves.
He first learnt to express himself through movement at his dance classes.
Words canâ€™t express (=it is impossible to describe)
how angry we felt
2 PARTICULAR EMOTION to show or describe a particular feeling Many of Munchâ€™s paintings express a deep feeling of despair.3 something expresses itself something expresses itself MATHEMATICS technical to change an amount or quantity into a different form, especially in mathematicsexpress something as/in something Express three-quarters as a decimal. The value of the coffee becomes significantly higher when expressed in foreign currency.5 FEEDING BABIES if a woman express milk, she presses milk out of her breast in order to feed it to her baby later
express3 â—â—â—‹ noun
1 [countable usually singular] a train or bus that does not stop in many places and therefore travels quickly
Londonâ€“Gatwick Express/Orient Express (=a fast train or bus which does a particular journey regularly)
2 [uncountable] a post service that delivers letters and packages very quickly
Send these books by express.
express2 â—â—â—‹ adjective [only before noun]
1 deliberate and for a specific situation
The school was founded with the express purpose of teaching deaf children.
2 clear and definite
express agreement/consent/authority etc
He is not to leave without my express permission.
Matthew left express instructions to keep all doors locked.
3 express train/coach/bus
4 express post/mail
5 American English designed to help you move through a place more quickly
express lanes on the freeway
an express line at a supermarket (=where people with only a few things to buy go to pay)

flashcards.title: fancy
flashcards.definition:
1 LIKE/WANT British English informal to like or want something, or want to do something SYN feel like
Fancy a quick drink, Emma?
fancy doing something
Sorry, but I donâ€™t fancy going out tonight.
2 SEXUAL ATTRACTION British English informal to feel sexually attracted to someone
All the girls fancied him.
3 fancy yourself
to behave in a way that shows you think you are very attractive or clever
That bloke on the dance floor really fancies himself.
4 fancy yourself (as) something
5 THINK SOMETHING WILL BE SUCCESSFUL British English to think someone or something is likely to be successful in something
Which team do you fancy this year?
I donâ€™t fancy our chances of getting a ticket this late.
6 fancy!/fancy that!
7 THINK/BELIEVE literary to think or believe something without being certain
fancy (that)
She fancied she heard a noise downstairs.
fancy noun
1 LIKING/WISH [singular] especially British English
a) a feeling, especially one that is not particularly strong or urgent, that you like someone or want to have something
take a fancy to somebody/something (=decide that you like someone or want to have something)
Mr Hill took a real fancy to Clara.
Wanting to go to Mexico was just a passing fancy (=the feeling did not last long).
Because of its high cost, a carpet is not an item that you change as the fancy takes you (=whenever you want).
b) take/catch your fancy if something takes or catches your fancy, you like it or want to have it
Did you see anything that took your fancy?
2 tickle somebodyâ€™s fancy
3 IDEA [countable] old-fashioned an idea or opinion that is not based on fact
Oh, that was just a fancy of his.
4 IMAGINATION [uncountable] literary imagination or something that you imagine flight of fancy
Fancy Adj
1 fancy hotels, restaurants, cars etc are expensive and fashionable SYN swanky
Harry took me to a fancy restaurant for our anniversary.
fancy prices British English (=very high and often unreasonable prices)
2 having a lot of decoration or bright colours, or made in a complicated way
fancy soaps in seashell shapes
I just want a basic sports coat â€“ nothing fancy.
3 complicated and needing a lot of skill OPP straightforward
I canâ€™t do all that fancy stuff on the computer.
Negotiating a deal can take some fancy footwork (=skill at making deals).
4 [only before noun] American English fancy food is of a high quality

flashcards.title: fault
flashcards.definition:
1 RESPONSIBLE FOR MISTAKE if something bad that has happened is your fault, you should be blamed for it, because you made a mistake or failed to do something
Iâ€™m really sorry â€“ itâ€™s all my fault.
be somebodyâ€™s fault (that)
Itâ€™s your fault weâ€™re late.
I didnâ€™t sleep well that night, but it was my own fault.
be somebodyâ€™s fault for doing something
Itâ€™s my fault for not making your new job clearer.
2 at fault
3 SOMETHING WRONG WITH SOMETHING
a) something that is wrong with a machine, system, design etc, which prevents it from working properly
a design fault
fault in
It sounds as if thereâ€™s a fault in one of the loudspeakers.
b) something that is wrong with something, which could be improved SYN flaw
There are two serious faults in Hobsbawmâ€™s discussion of nationalism.
For all its faults (=in spite of its faults) we love this city.
c) a mistake in the way that something was made, which spoils its appearance
fault in
The sweater had a fault in it and I had to take it back.
4 SOMEBODYâ€™S CHARACTER a bad or weak part of someoneâ€™s character
His worst fault is his arrogance.
I may have my faults, but ingratitude is not one of them.
For all his faults (=in spite of his faults) he was a good father.
5 through no fault of her/my etc own
6 CRACK a large crack in the rocks that form the Earthâ€™s surface
the San Andreas fault
7 generous/loyal/honest etc to a fault
8 TENNIS a mistake made when a player is serving the ball in tennis
double fault, loyal, find fault with somebody/something

flashcards.title: fine
flashcards.definition:
fine adj
1 ACCEPTABLE [not before noun] especially spoken satisfactory or acceptable SYN OK
â€˜Weâ€™re meeting at 8.30.â€™ â€˜Okay, fine.â€™
looks/seems/sounds fine
In theory, the scheme sounds fine.
If you want to use cheese instead of chicken, thatâ€™s fine.
â€˜Do you want chili sauce on it?â€™ â€˜No, itâ€™s fine as it is, thanks.â€™
Iâ€™m fine (thanks/thank you) spoken (=used when telling someone that you do not want any more when they offer you something)
â€˜More coffee?â€™ â€˜No, Iâ€™m fine, thanks.â€™
thatâ€™s fine by me/thatâ€™s fine with me etc spoken (=used when saying that you do not mind about something)
If Scott wanted to keep his life secret, that was fine by her.
2 HEALTHY in good health SYN OK
â€˜How are you?â€™ â€˜Fine, thanks, how are you?â€™
I feel fine, really.
â–º see thesaurus at healthy
3 VERY GOOD [usually before noun] very good or of a very high standard
Many people regard Beethovenâ€™s fifth symphony as his finest work.
Heâ€™s a very fine player.
Itâ€™s a fine idea.
Hatfield House is a fine example of Jacobean architecture.
The restaurant was chosen for its good food and fine wines.
â–º see thesaurus at good
4 WEATHER bright and not raining
If itâ€™s fine tomorrow weâ€™ll go out.
a fine day/morning/evening
I hope it stays fine for you.
5 NARROW very thin or narrow
Fine needles are inserted in the arm.
a fine thread
very fine hairs
6 DELICATE [usually before noun] attractive, neat, and delicate
fine china
Her dark hair accentuates her fine features (=nose, eyes, cheeks etc).
7 SMALL
a) fine details, changes, differences etc are very small and therefore difficult to understand or notice
We stayed up discussing the finer points of Marxist theory.
b) in small grains, pieces, or drops
A fine drizzle started falling.
a mixture of fine and coarse breadcrumbs
c) fine material is made so that the spaces between the threads are very small
fine netting
scarlet cloth with a very fine weave
8 BAD [only before noun] especially spoken used humorously to say that someone or something is bad in some way
Thatâ€™s another fine mess (=bad situation) heâ€™s got himself into.
Youâ€™re a fine one to talk (=you are criticizing someone for something you do yourself).
9 SPEECH/WORDS sounding important and impressive, but probably not true or honest
Only time will tell whether these fine sentiments will translate into action.
10 a fine man/woman etc
11 a fine line between something and something
12 get something down to a fine art
13 not to put too fine a point on it
14 finer feelings
15 a fine figure of a man/woman
16 somebodyâ€™s finest hour

1 especially spoken in a way that is satisfactory or acceptable
â€˜Howâ€™s it going?â€™ â€˜Fine, thanks.â€™
The dress fitted me fine.

2 do fine
3 if you cut something fine, you cut it into very small or very thin pieces SYN finely
fine3 â—â—â—‹ verb [transitive]
to make someone pay money as a punishment
fine somebody for (doing) something
She was fined for speeding.
fine somebody Â£200/$500 etc
The club was fined Â£50,000 for financial irregularities.

flashcards.title: force
flashcards.definition:
1 MILITARY
a) [countable usually plural] a group of people who have been trained to do military work for a government or other organization
government/military/defence etc forces
The riots were suppressed by government forces.
He strengthened US forces in the Gulf.
a plan to disarm the rebel forces (=those fighting against the government)
b) the forces British English the army, navy, and air force
in the forces
Both her sons are in the forces.
c) nuclear/conventional forces nuclear weapons or ordinary weapons
short-range nuclear forces
air force, armed forces, ground forces, peacekeeping force, security forces(1), task force(2)
2 MILITARY ACTION [uncountable] military action used as a way of achieving your aims
Peace cannot be imposed by force.
The UN will allow the use of force against aircraft violating the zone.
3 VIOLENCE [uncountable] violent physical action used to get what you want
The police used force to overpower the demonstrators.
by force
In the end he had to be thrown out of the house by force.
They kicked the door down using sheer brute force.
4 PHYSICAL POWER [uncountable] the amount of physical power with which something moves or hits another thing strength
force of
The force of the explosion blew out all the windows.
with great/considerable/increasing etc force
He raised his hand and struck her with terrifying force.
5 NATURAL POWER [countable, uncountable] a natural power or event
the force of gravity
powerful natural forces such as earthquakes, floods, and drought
the forces of nature
6 ORGANIZED GROUP [countable usually singular] a group of people who have been trained and organized to do a particular job
the companyâ€™s sales force
the quality of the teaching force
police force
7 STRONG INFLUENCE [countable] something or someone who is powerful and has a lot of influence on the way things happen
the driving force (behind something/somebody) (=the person or thing that makes something happen)
Betty Coward was the driving force behind the project.
a force for change/peace/democracy etc (=someone or something that makes change, peace etc more likely to happen)
Healthy competition is a force for innovation.
Heâ€™s a quick and decisive player â€“ a force to be reckoned with (=a person, team, company etc that influences what happens).
The fall in prices was due to forces beyond their control.
market forces
8 POWERFUL EFFECT [uncountable] the powerful effect that something has on you
Even after 30 years, the play has lost noun of its force.
the force of his personality
9 join/combine forces (with somebody/something)
10 in force
11 come into force/bring something into force
12 by/through/out of force of habit
13 by/through force of circumstance(s)
14 WIND
a) force 8/9/10 etc a unit for measuring the strength of the wind
b) gale/hurricane force wind extremely strong wind that does a lot of damage
[english)

The police used force to overpower the demonstrators.
by force
In the end he had to be thrown out of the house by force.

4 PHYSICAL POWER [uncountable] the amount of physical power with which something moves or hits another thing â†’ strength

force of
The force of the explosion blew out all the windows.
with great/considerable/increasing etc force
He raised his hand and struck her with terrifying force.

5 NATURAL POWER [countable, uncountable] a natural power or event

the force of gravity
powerful natural forces such as earthquakes, floods, and drought
the forces of nature

6 ORGANIZED GROUP [countable usually singular] a group of people who have been trained and organized to do a particular job

the companyâ€™s sales force
the quality of the teaching force
â†’ police force

7 STRONG INFLUENCE [countable] something or someone who is powerful and has a lot of influence on the way things happen

the driving force (behind something/somebody) (=the person or thing that makes something happen)
Betty Coward was the driving force behind the project.
a force for change/peace/democracy etc (=someone or something that makes change, peace etc more likely to happen)
Healthy competition is a force for innovation.
Heâ€™s a quick and decisive player â€“ a force to be reckoned with (=a person, team, company etc that influences what happens).
The fall in prices was due to forces beyond their control.
â†’ market forces

8 POWERFUL EFFECT [uncountable] the powerful effect that something has on you
Even after 30 years, the play has lost noun of its force.
the force of his personality

9 â†’ join/combine forces (with somebody/something)

10 â†’ in force
11 â†’ come into force/bring something into force
12 â†’ by/through/out of force of habit
13 â†’ by/through force of circumstance(s)
14 WIND
a) force 8/9/10 etc a unit for measuring the strength of the wind
b) gale/hurricane force wind extremely strong wind that does a lot of damage

flashcards.definition:
1 MORE more, or to a greater degree
A spokesman declined to comment until the evidence could be studied further.
The flavour of the wine is further improved during the aging period.

further into/away etc
Marcus sank further and further into debt.
â–º see thesaurus at more
2 take something further
3 DISTANCE (also farther) a greater distance, or beyond a particular place
They walked a little further.
further up/away/along etc
His farm is located further away from Riobamba than his brotherâ€™s.
His hands moved further down her back.
Theyâ€™ve never been further south than San Diego.
4 TIME into the past or the future
further back/on/ahead etc
Five years further on, a cure has still not been found.
The records donâ€™t go any further back than 1960.
It might be a sign, much further down the road (=in the future), of a change in policy.
5 IN ADDITION [sentence adverb] formal used to introduce something additional that you want to talk about SYN furthermore
Butter sales have fallen because margarine has improved in flavor. Further, butter consumption has decreased because of links to heart disease.
6 further to something
7 nothing could be further from the truth

1 LIKE SOMEBODY especially British English if people get on, they like each other and have a friendly relationship with each other
with
Iâ€™ve always got on well with Henry.
The two boys get on well most of the time.
2 PROGRESS to deal with a job or situation or to make progress
How is George getting on at school?
with
How are you getting on with your essay?
without
I donâ€™t know how weâ€™ll get on without Michael.
3 CONTINUE DOING SOMETHING to continue doing something
with
Be quiet and get on with your work!
4 BE SUCCESSFUL to be successful in your job
Youâ€™ll have to work hard if you want to get on.
5 CLOTHING get something on to put a piece of clothing on
I canâ€™t get my boots on!
6 be getting on
a) if time is getting on, it is quite late
Come on, itâ€™s getting on and we ought to go home.
I realized that time was getting on and we would have to hurry.
b) informal if someone is getting on, they are quite old
7 getting on for 90/10 oâ€™clock/2,000 etc almost a particular age, time, number etc. to move toward becoming
Mrs McIntyre must be getting on for 90 by now.
The total cost was getting on for $100,000.
8 get it on American English informal to have sex
9 get on with it! spoken used to tell someone to hurry

10 let somebody get on with it informal to let someone do something on their own, and not help them or tell them what to do
She wanted to decorate her room, so I just let her get on with it.

flashcards.title: give-up
flashcards.definition:
1 give something â†” up
to stop doing something, especially something that you do regularly
Darren has decided to give up football at the end of this season.
She gave up her job and started writing poetry.
give up doing something
I gave up going to the theatre when I moved out of London.
Why donâ€™t you give up smoking?
2 to stop trying to do something
We spent half an hour looking for the keys, but eventually gave up and went home.
I give up.
Whatâ€™s the answer? You shouldnâ€™t give up so easily.
give up doing something
I gave up trying to persuade him to continue with his studies.
give something â†” up
She has still not given up the search.
The ground was too hard to dig so I gave it up as a bad job (=stopped trying because success seemed unlikely).
3 give yourself/somebody up to allow yourself or someone else to be catch by the police or enemy soldier
The siege ended peacefully after the gunman gave himself up.
give yourself/somebody up to
In the end, his family gave him up to the police.
4 give up something to use some of your time to do a particular thing
I donâ€™t mind giving up a couple of hours a week to deal with correspondence.
5 give something/somebody â†” up to give something that is yours to someone else
The family refused to give up any of their land.
She was put under tremendous pressure to give the baby up.
give something/somebody â†” up to
I would always give my seat up to an elderly person on the bus.
6 give somebody â†” up to end a romantic relationship with someone, even though you do not really want to
I knew deep down that I should give him up.
7 give somebody up for dead/lost etc to believe that someone is dead and stop looking for them
The ship sank and the crew were given up for dead.
8 give it up for somebody spoken informal used to ask people to applaud someone
[)
flashcards.example:
give up
â€¢ Americans love their cars, and no-one is going to persuade them to give them up.
â€¢ I used to really enjoy dancing, but I had to give it up after I became ill.
â€¢ Fania was prepared to give up all her jewelry to help her father get out of debt.
â€¢ She gave up drinking over 10 years ago.
â€¢ As he grew older he gave up going for walks and seldom went out.
â€¢ He gave up his job so that he could look after his wife.
â€¢ I made several attempts to repair the damage, but gave up in the end.
â€¢ If you smoke, try to give up or at least cut down.
â€¢ We will never give up our struggle.
â€¢ After the accident she had to give up riding and farming.
â€¢ I've given up trying to get her to change her mind.
â€¢ We did start a protest, but gave it up when we realized we would never be successful.
â€¢ Come on, don't give up yet!

give up doing something
â€¢ I gave up smoking when I got pregnant.
â€¢ Vladimir has given up trying to teach her Russian.

give up... easily
â€¢ As for myself, I am not one to give up his passions easily.
â€¢ In any case, neither bird gives up its secrets easily.
â€¢ Still, this wasn't a fellow to give up easily.
â€¢ These are titles I cherish and do not intend to give up easily.
â€¢ They did not give up their privileges easily.
â€¢ Whatever it is beneath the sunny waves, it is not giving up easily.
â€¢ When challenged, he may give up easily and retreat to his own world.
â€¢ These students tend to have poor tolerance for frustration and give up easily when tasks become difficult. 23.

give yourself/somebody up
â€¢ He is not going to give that up.
â€¢ I kept starting new regimes, then finding I couldn't give them up.
â€¢ I had to give the ball up, and then I had work my butt off to get it back.
â€¢ That's why I want to give it up for adoption.
â€¢ But then, why give them up so abruptly?
â€¢ In return for our consent, he swore he would give it up the day after he won the election.
â€¢ But we would not give it up without a desperate struggle.

give to
â€¢ They gave bonuses of up to $ 1,000 per person to reward outstanding group effort.
â€¢ He also wants to give families up to $ 10,000 in annual tax deductions for college costs.
â€¢ She gave that up to become a secretary.
â€¢ They were both dead by the time Goulais gave himself up to the police.
â€¢ Printer and scanner performed well, but neither gave results up to the specification of the rest of the system.
â€¢ Will they give themselves up to the tribunal?

give somebody up for dead/lost etc
â€¢ After much searching, the village people gave Kay up for dead.
â€¢ Gray had been missing for over a year, and his wife was ready to give him up for dead.
â€¢ On the thirteenth day, Kasturbai knelt before a sacred plant and prayed; she had given him up for lost.
â€¢ It is as if he gave them up for dead when they left Shiloh.
