flashcards.title: gossip
flashcards.definition:
1 [uncountable] information that is passed from one person to another about other peopleâ€™s behaviour and private lives, often including unkind or untrue remark
gossip about
Hereâ€™s an interesting piece of gossip about Mrs Smith.
Whatâ€™s the latest gossip?
Do you want to hear some juicy gossip?
She had no time for idle gossip.
It was common gossip how he felt about her.
2 [countable usually singular] a conversation in which you exchange information with someone about other peopleâ€™s lives and things that have happened
Philâ€™s in there, having a gossip with Maggie.
3 [countable] someone who likes talking about other peopleâ€™s private lives â€“ used to show disapproval
Rickâ€™s a terrible gossip.
gossip Verb
to talk about other peopleâ€™s behaviour and private lives, often including remarks that are unkind or untrue
gossip about
The whole town was gossiping about them.
[english)
flashcards.example:
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + GOSSIP
the latest gossip
Annie usually has all the latest gossip.

juicy gossip (=interesting gossip)
He said that he had some especially juicy gossip to tell us.

hot gossip (=interesting gossip)
Whatâ€™s the latest hot gossip going round at work then?

idle gossip (=gossip not based on facts)
She had no time for idle gossip.

common gossip (=gossip that everyone knows about)
Rumours about her affairs had become common gossip.

office gossip
He told her a few bits of office gossip which he thought might interest her.
village gossip British English:
She knew from village gossip how Harry had treated his first wife.
malicious gossip (=unkind gossip that is likely to upset someone)
Has someone been spreading malicious gossip?
PHRASES
a piece of gossip
Iâ€™ve got an interesting piece of gossip which might interest you.
be the subject of gossip (=be talked about)
His close friendship with Carol was the subject of gossip.
VERBS
exchange gossip (=talk about other people and their private lives with someone)
They used to meet up and exchange gossip.
hear gossip
Have you heard the latest gossip about Steve?
listen to gossip
He was always willing to listen to gossip.
spread gossip
Someoneâ€™s been spreading gossip about Lucy and Ian.
gossip goes around (=it is told by one person to another)
It was a small village, and any gossip went around very quickly.

flashcards.title: handle
flashcards.definition:
1- DO WORK to do the things that are necessary to complete a job
I handled most of the paperwork.
The case is being handled by a top lawyer.
The finance department handles all the accounts.
Computers can handle huge amounts of data.
2- DEAL WITH A SITUATION [transitive] to deal with a situation or problem by behave in a particular way and making particular decision
The headmaster handled the situation very well.
I knew I had handled the matter badly.
3- DEAL WITH A PERSON [transitive] to deal with a person or behave towards them in a particular way, especially in order to keep them happy
Some customers are quite difficult to handle.
4- NOT BECOME UPSET [transitive] to not become upset in a difficult situation
She canâ€™t handle it when people criticize her.
5- HOLD [transitive] to touch something or pick it up and hold it in your hands
He had never handled a weapon before.
6- CONTROL A VEHICLE
a) to control the movement of a vehicle or an animal
I didnâ€™t know if Iâ€™d be able to handle such a large vehicle.
b) the way a vehicle handle is how easy it is to control
handles well/badly
The car handles well, even on wet roads.
7- MOVE GOODS [transitive] to move goods from one place to another
The Post Office handles nearly 2 billion letters and parcels over the Christmas period.
8 BUY/SELL GOODS to buy or sell goods Bennet was charged with handling stolen goods.
[english)

flashcards.title: hang
flashcards.definition:
1 TOP PART FASTENED
a) [transitive always + adverb / preposition] (also hang up)
to put something in a position so that the top part is fix or support, and the bottom part is free to move and does not touch the ground
Philip hung his coat on a hook behind the door.
She hung the sheets on the washing line.
b) [intransitive always + adverb / preposition]
to be in a position where the top part is fixed or supported, and the bottom part is free to move and does not touch the ground
An old-fashioned gas lamp hung from the ceiling.
Her long hair hung loose about her shoulders.
The shirt hung down almost to his ankles.
2 PICTURE ETC
a) [transitive] to fix a picture, photograph etc to a wall
I wanted to hang the picture in the hall.
b) [intransitive always + adverb / preposition]
if a picture, photograph etc is hang somewhere, it is fixed to a wall
There was a family photograph hanging on the wall.
c) be hung with something if the walls of a room are hung with pictures or decoration, the pictures etc are on the walls
The entrance hall was hung with rich tapestries.
3 KILL/BE KILLED (past tense and past participle hanged) [intransitive, transitive] to kill someone by drop them with a rope around their neck, or to die in this way, especially as a punishment for a serious crime
be hanged for something
He was hanged for murder.
hang yourself
Corey hanged himself in his prison cell.
If he is found guilty, he will almost certainly hang.
4 PAPER [transitive] to fasten attractive paper to a wall in order to decorate a room
We spent the afternoon hanging wallpaper.
5 DOOR [transitive] to fasten a door in position
Hanging a door is quite a tricky job.
6 MIST/SMOKE/SMELL
if something such as smoke hangs in the air, it stay in the air for a long time
The smoke from the bonfires hung in the air.
A thick mist hung over the town.
7 hang open hang open
if a door, someoneâ€™s mouth etc hang open, it is open
8 hang in the balance hang in the balance
9 hang by a thread hang by a thread
10 hang on in there hang on in there
11 hang your head hang your head
12 hang fire hang fire
13 leave something hanging in the air leave something hanging in the air
14 hang a right left hang a right left
15 [intransitive] American English spoken to spend time somewhere, relax and enjoy yourself
hang with
We were just hanging with the dudes at Mikeâ€™s house.
16 i ll be hanged if i ll be hanged if
17 hang it all hang it all
18 hang something hang something
19 i you might as well be hanged for a sheep as for a lamb i you might as well be hanged for a sheep as for a lamb
hang about hang about
hang about with hang about with
hang around round hang around round
hang around with hang around with
hang back hang back
hang on hang on
hang on to hang on to
hang out hang out
hang over hang over
hang together hang together
hang up hang up
[english)

flashcards.title: heading back
flashcards.definition:
For example:
I'm heading back home
I'm going back home
Mostly the same!
'Heading back' is more colloquial, but they are both informal (formally, we might say 'returning home').
One difference is 'heading back' refers to leaving a temporary place (restaurant, friend's house, etc.). It would usually be used to mean 'walking/driving back to one's house'.
'Going back' could mean leaving a temporary place, OR travelling further (from a trip).
Ex. My mom is GOING BACK to Puerto Rico to visit her family.

flashcards.title: hit-spot
flashcards.definition:
"Hit-spot" most commonly refers to the idiom "hit the spot," meaning to be exactly what's needed or to satisfy a craving (like "that cool drink really hit the spot"), but can also mean a popular place ("hot spot"), a sensitive body area, or even slang for a specific way to smoke cannabis. The exact meaning depends on the context, but usually, it implies perfect satisfaction or high popularity.
Common Meanings:
Hit the Spot (Idiom): To be perfectly satisfying or just right for a need or craving.
Example: "After hiking all day, a hot meal really hit the spot".
Hot Spot (Popular Place): A trendy, busy, or active location, like a restaurant or club.
Example: "That new cafe is the latest hot spot in town".
Sensitive Spot (Body): A tender or painful area on the body, often related to injury or massage.
Cannabis Slang (Spots): Small pieces of cannabis used in a method called "spotting" or "knifing".

flashcards.title: horrify
flashcards.definition:
to make someone feel very shock and upset or afraid

horrified to see/hear/find etc
She was horrified to discover that he loved Rose.
[english)
flashcards.example:
horrify
â€¢ Meg watched, fascinated and horrified, as he probed inside the animal, the blood dark on his fingers.
â€¢ Groups representing disabled people were horrified at the proposals.
â€¢ I was horrified by her swollen and distended stomach.
â€¢ The President and I exchanged quick, horrified glances.
â€¢ I was horrified to find out later that in fact he had not collected her from school but from the police station.
â€¢ As Theresa would probably be horrified to hear.
â€¢ You are horrified, you can not think straight, as you stare at the broken body.
horrified to see/hear/find etc
â€¢ As Theresa would probably be horrified to hear.
â€¢ You are horrified to see a small foot sticking out from behind your rear tire.
â€¢ When we had entered the house, however, I was horrified to see Heathcliff lock the front door.
â€¢ She was horrified to see how quickly the opportunistic infection took hold.
â€¢ I was horrified to find out later that in fact he had not collected her from school but from the police station.
â€¢ Jessamy was horrified to find that a wave of pure jealousy was beginning to sweep through her.
â€¢ But, once she began thinking along those lines, she was horrified to find that she could not stop.
â€¢ O was horrified to see that the man was actually crying.

b) used to say that you have suddenly had an idea, thought of a solution to a problem etc

c) used to stop someone from interrupting because they have an opinion about what you are saying

flashcards.title: invite
flashcards.definition:
(noun) invitation invite (adjective) uninvited inviting â‰  uninviting (verb) invite (adverb) inviting
1 to ask someone to come to a party, wedding, meal etc
invite somebody to something
Who should we invite to the party?
invite somebody to do something
Gail invited me to stay with her while her husband was out of town.
invite somebody for something
Why donâ€™t you invite her for a drink at the club one evening?
Iâ€™m afraid I wasnâ€™t invited.
GRAMMAR: Prepositions with invite
â€¢ You invite someone to an event or a place:
Did they invite you to the wedding?
She invited me to her house.
â€¢ You invite someone for a meal or a period of time:
He invited us for brunch.
Iâ€™ll invite them for the weekend.
2 to politely ask someone to do something
invite somebody to do something
Anyone interested in contributing articles is invited to contact the editor.
3 to encourage something bad to happen, especially without intending to
Any government that sells arms to dictators is inviting trouble.
invite somebody along
invite somebody back
invite somebody in
invite somebody out
invite somebody over
[english)
flashcards.example:
invite
â€¢ Perhaps movie marketers should have been more careful about inviting comparisons.
â€¢ Applications for this position are invited from all individuals with relevant experience.
â€¢ Not to provide aid will just invite further catastrophe in the area.
â€¢ In fact, their purpose in inviting him to lunch was to ask him to divorce her.
â€¢ What he doesn't do in contrast to his practice with musical guests is to invite Jazzie to talk.

flashcards.title: involve
flashcards.definition:
1 if an activity or situation involves something, that thing is part of it or a result of it

I didnâ€™t realize putting on a play involved so much work.
involve doing something

2 to include or affect someone or something

There have been four accidents involving Forest Service planes.
3 to ask or allow someone to take part in something
involve somebody in (doing) something

flashcards.title: lane

1 a narrow road in the countryside path
a quiet country lane
2 a road in a city, often used in road names
the Hilton Hotel in Park Lane
a network of alleys and back lanes (=narrow unimportant roads, often behind a row of houses)
3 one of the two or three parallel areas on a road which are divided by painted lines to keep traffic apart
That idiot changed lanes without signalling.
the inside/middle/outside lane
Use the outside lane for overtaking only.
the fast/slow lane
Cars in the fast lane were travelling at over 80 miles an hour.
three-lane motorway/highway/road
bus lane, cycle lane
4 one of the narrow parallel areas marked for each competitor in a running or swimming race
5 a line or course along which ships or aircraft regularly travel between ports or airports
busy shipping lanes

The kids tumbled around on the floor, laughing hysterically.
He couldnâ€™t help it; he burst out laughing (=suddenly started laughing).
laugh your head off

flashcards.title: Lay the table
flashcards.definition:
"Lay the table" means to prepare a dining table for a meal by arranging plates, cutlery (forks, knives, spoons), glasses, and napkins, synonymous with "set the table," a common British English phrase, while Americans often prefer "set the table". It involves placing items in their proper spots for each diner, from simple place settings to formal arrangements.

1 a long talk on a particular subject that someone gives to a group of people, especially to students in a university speech

My father caught me and gave me a long lecture about the dangers of drink.
Lecture Verb
1 [transitive] to talk angrily or seriously to someone in order to criticize or warn them, in a way that they think is unfair or unnecessary
I wish youâ€™d stop lecturing me!
lecture somebody about/on something
He began to lecture us about making too much noise.
2 [intransitive] to talk to a group of people on a particular subject, especially to students in a university
lecture on
He lectures on European art at Manchester University.

flashcards.title: major
flashcards.definition:
1 [usually before noun] having very serious or worrying results OPP minor
There is a major problem with parking in London.
The loss of their goalkeeper through injury was a major setback for the team.
He underwent major heart surgery recently.
It could have sparked a major confrontation.
â–º see thesaurus at important, main
2 [usually before noun] very large or important, when compared to other things or people of a similar kind OPP minor
major role/part/factor etc
Britain played a major role in the negotiations.
There are two major political parties in the US.
The governmentâ€™s major concern is with preventing road accidents.
Smoking is one of the major causes of cancer.
the major developments in computer technology
a major road
â–º see thesaurus at big
3 [not before noun] American English spoken very important
This is major? You got me out of bed for this?
4 a major key is based on a musical scale in which there are semitones between the third and fourth and the seventh and eighth notes minor
a symphony in D major
noun Major
1 an officer of middle rank in the British or US army or Marines, or in the US air force drum major
2 especially American English the main subject that a student studies at college or university
Her major is history.
3 American English someone studying a particular subject as their main subject at college or university
Sheâ€™s a history major.

flashcards.title: make-up-for
flashcards.definition:
1 to make a bad situation better, or replace something that has been lost SYN compensate
The team will be anxious to make up for a disappointing start to the season.
I donâ€™t eat breakfast but I make up for it at lunch.
The good days more than make up for the bad ones.
2 to have so much of one quality that it is not important that you do not have much of another one
in/with
What Jay lacked in experience, he made up for in enthusiasm.
Caroline doesnâ€™t have a natural talent for music but she makes up for it with hard work.
3 to do something to show that you are sorry for doing something that upset or annoy someone
Iâ€™m sorry I was late. To make up for it, let me treat you to a meal.
4 make up for lost timea) to work more quickly, or at times when you do not usually work, because something has prevent you from doing the work before
We rehearsed all day Saturday, to make up for lost time.
b) to do a lot of something in an eager way because you have not had a chance to do it before
Palin didnâ€™t travel much as a young man but heâ€™s certainly made up for lost time now.
[)
flashcards.example:
make up for
â€¢ But her unflagging ambition more than made up for her shortcomings.
â€¢ Still, seven minutes later Magilton made up for his miss.
â€¢ Its looks are ordinary, but what it lacks aesthetically it makes up for in crisp handling and user-friendliness.
â€¢ Publishers of best-sellers have something to gain from discounting if volumes rise enough to make up for it.
â€¢ But the New York baseball writers made up for that.
â€¢ I had to make up for the ravages of time.
â€¢ To make up for the unkindness, he made a bad and nervous joke.
â€¢ They had the opportunity to make up for this loss by sharing in 40 years of prosperity under a democratic system.
more than make up for
â€¢ She also quickly realized that economic prosperity would more than make up for her political defeat.
â€¢ But her unflagging ambition more than made up for her shortcomings.
â€¢ What it lacked in standard, it more than made up for in atmosphere and in a deep appreciation of athletics.
â€¢ What Sugar Bowl lacked in high-tech development, it more than made up for in the bounty of what really counts.
â€¢ But it more than makes up for that in charm and grace.
â€¢ As lovers they were not exactly vibrant, but their voices and Lehar's music more than made up for that.
â€¢ The tutorial supplied is excellent and more than makes up for the formal style of the manuals.
â€¢ The quality of the sound however more than makes up for this.
make in/with
â€¢ But it more than makes up for that in charm and grace.
â€¢ It is already becoming clear that services will not make up for the decline in hard goods production.
â€¢ Only part of this is an effort to make up for being in her way.
â€¢ If you have a personal pension, this year is the last opportunity to make up for missed contributions in previous years.
â€¢ Textiles were excluded and there was no significant increases in the sugar quota to make up for cuts in recent years.
â€¢ Mario got the preferred equipment and Ronnie made up for it in sheer aggression.
â€¢ Huddersfield made up for their failure in the Cup by winning the League Championship in the next season, 1923-4.
â€¢ In some years, he has made up for losing marks in the regular season by increasing his bets in the playoffs.
make up for lost time
â€¢ He's girl crazy! He went to a boys' school and now he's making up for lost time.
â€¢ The bus driver was speeding to make up for lost time.
â€¢ Meanwhile Keith and Mae are settling down to married life, making up for lost time.
â€¢ noun the less, we immediately started our other meetings to make up for lost time.
â€¢ Once I settled into my new life, I did everything I could to make up for lost time.
â€¢ Time to make up for lost time.
â€¢ He was eager to make up for lost time and published prolifically.

flashcards.title: make-up-your-mind-make-your-mind-up
flashcards.definition:
a) to decide which of two or more choice you want, especially after thinking for a long time
I wish heâ€™d hurry up and make his mind up.
make up your mind/make your mind up about
He couldnâ€™t make up his mind about what to do with the money.
make up your mind whether
Karen couldnâ€™t make up her mind whether to apply for membership or not.
b) to become very determine to do something, so that you will not change your decision No more argument.
My mind is made up.
make up your mind to do something
He had clearly made up his mind to end the affair.
make up your mind that
I made up my mind there and then that I would never get married.
c) to decide what your opinion is about someone or something
make up your mind/make your mind up about
I could never really make my mind up about him.
Youâ€™re old enough to make your own mind up about smoking.

flashcards.title: mostly
flashcards.definition:
used to talk about most members of a group, most occasions, most parts of something etc SYN mainly
Green teas are mostly from China or Japan.
There were about fifteen people in the lounge, mostly women.
He blamed his parents. Mostly he blamed his dad.
Register
In written English, people often prefer to use generally or for the most part rather than mostly, because they sound more formal:
Many tourists visit the region, generally for skiing.
The inhabitants of the village are for the most part elderly.

flashcards.title: narrow
flashcards.definition:
1 NOT WIDE
measure only a small distance from one side to the other, especially in relation to the length OPP wide
broadnarrow street/road/path etc
a long narrow road
the narrow passage between the cottage and the house
his narrow bed
The stairs were very narrow.
a long, narrow band of cloud
2 narrow escape narrow escape
3 narrow victory defeat majority margin etc narrow victory defeat majority margin etc
4 IDEAS/ATTITUDES a narrow attitude or way of looking at a situation is too limit and does not consider enough possibility OPP broad
Youâ€™ve got a very narrow view of life.
Some teachers have a narrow vision of what art is.
narrow minded narrow minded
5 narrow sense definition narrow sense definition
6 LIMITED limited in range or number of things OPP broad
The company offered only a narrow range of financial services.
narrowness noun [uncountable]
narrowly narrowly narrows narrows,
the straight and narrow
[english)
flashcards.example:
Nordic skis are longer, narrower and lighter than Alpine skis.
â€¢ Their interpretation of Christianity is narrow and limiting.
â€¢ Columns that are too narrow are unattractive and difficult to read.
â€¢ We have a long narrow area and the motorway has cut it in half.
â€¢ a narrow black tie
â€¢ a narrow examination of events
â€¢ The road was too narrow for me to overtake the car in front.
â€¢ She climbed through a narrow gap in the fence.
â€¢ Plants cultivated in half-shade have very narrow leaves and resemble some species of Aponogeton.
â€¢ He stood now flush against the side of the bluff on a narrow ledge, his hands over his face.
â€¢ Adjust the starting point so that you avoid a very narrow margin at the perimeter.
â€¢ The Dow, the most closely followed index, though a much narrower one, started the decade at 2,753.
â€¢ A steep, narrow path led down through the woods to the beach.
â€¢ I see narrow roads contoured into the sides of steep slopes.
â€¢ The landed nobility provided tsarism with a perilously narrow social base.
â€¢ There was a narrow stone path, Alexei now saw, around the base of the promontory beyond the buttress.
â€¢ the narrow streets of Italian cities

flashcards.title: notice
flashcards.definition:
1 if you notice something or someone, you realize that they exist, especially because you can see, hear, or feel them
He noticed a woman in a black dress sitting across from him.
I didnâ€™t notice any smoke. Have you noticed any change in him?
notice (that)
I noticed that her hands were shaking.
He never seems to notice when people take advantage of him.
notice who/what/how etc
She hadnâ€™t noticed before quite how grey his hair was.
notice somebody/something doing something
Did you notice him leaving the party early?
GRAMMAR: Using the progressive
Notice is not used in the progressive.
You say:I notice youâ€™re wearing glasses.
âœ—Donâ€™t say: Iâ€™m noticing youâ€™re wearing glasses.
2 be noticed get somebody noticed be noticed get somebody noticed
to get attention, or to make someone get attention
These clothes will get you noticed and enhance your image.
3 somebody can t help noticing something somebody can t help noticing something
(also somebody canâ€™t help but notice something) if someone canâ€™t help noticing something, they realize that it exist or is happening even though they are not deliberately trying to pay attention to it
I couldnâ€™t help noticing the bruises on her arm.
THESAURUS
notice to realize that something is there or that something is happening, because you can see, hear, or feel it
I noticed that he was rather quiet during dinner.
Children donâ€™t seem to notice the cold.
â€˜Julieâ€™s home.â€™ â€˜Yes, I noticed her bicycle outside.â€™
detect to notice something that is difficult to see, hear etc because it is very small, faint, or unclear. Detect is used about people and machine, and is more formal than notice
X-ray telescopes can now detect virtually every type of astronomical object.
He thought he detected a flicker of interest in her eyes.
spot to notice something, especially something that is difficult to see or that you see for a short time only. Spot is more informal than notice
Can you spot the difference between these two pictures?
Iâ€™m glad you spotted the mistake before it was too late.
become aware/conscious to gradually begin to notice that something is happening or is trueI became aware that
Mum was getting a lot older.Tessa became conscious of a feeling of guilt.
can tell to be able to notice something because you can see, smell, hear it etc
I could tell that she had been drinking.
Can you tell Iâ€™ve lost weight?
something/somebody catches your eye used to say that you suddenly notice something or someone because they are interesting, attractive, or good at something
I saw this shirt in the shop window and it just caught my eye.
Clarke caught the eye of boss Bryan Robson when he scored for Newry last week.
observe formal to notice something as a result of watch or study it closely
Psychologists observed that the mice became more aggressive in smaller cages.
perceive formal to notice something, especially that something is happening, or is true, or needs to be done
The company quickly perceived the need for change.
Doctors perceive that they do not have adequate time to spend with their patients.
witness to see something happen because you are there at the timePeople have witnessed some great economic changes during the last ten years.
miss to not notice something because it is difficult to seeItâ€™s easy to miss the entrance â€“ the sign is hidden behind a tree.

flashcards.title: OnTime inTime
flashcards.definition:
â€œJust in timeâ€ means at the last possible moment, exactly before itâ€™s too late.
Simple meaning:
â€¢ Exactly on time
â€¢ Not early, not late
Examples:
â€¢ He arrived just in time for the meeting.
(If he came later, the meeting would start.)
â€¢ We got to the station just in time to catch the train.

flashcards.title: operation
flashcards.definition:
1 MEDICAL [countable] the process of cutting into someoneâ€™s body to repair or remove a part that is damaged
operation on
Sheâ€™s going to need an operation on her ankle.
operation for
an operation for cancer
operation to do something
He had an operation to reduce the swelling in his brain.
2 BUSINESS/ORGANIZATION [countable] a business, company, or organization
The firm set up its own property development operation.
a microchip manufacturing operation
Nolan and Barnes were both involved in the operation.
3 WORK/ACTIVITIES [countable, uncountable] the work or activities done by a business or organization, or the process of doing this work
Many small businesses fail in the first year of operation.
The Education Business Partnership has been in operation since 1989.
4 ACTIONS [countable] a set of planned actions or activities for a particular purpose
The UN rescue operation started shortly after dawn.
5 MACHINE/SYSTEM [uncountable] the way the parts of a machine or system work together, or the process of making a machine or system work
The aircraftâ€™s engine operation was normal.
in operation
Protective clothing must be worn when the machine is in operation.
The device has a single button, allowing for easy operation.
Careful checks must be made before the factory commences operation.
The new investment system came into operation in 1999.
6 PRINCIPLE/LAW/PLAN ETC [uncountable] the way something such as a principle or law works or has an effect
in operation
a clear example of the law of gravity in operation
come/go into operation (=begin to have an effect)
The new rule comes into operation on February 1.
put/bring something into operation (=make something start to work)
A scheme is being brought into operation to see how these changes would work.
7 MILITARY/POLICE ACTION [countable] a planned military or police action, especially one that involves a lot of people
Britain will carry out a joint military operation with the US.
8 COMPUTERS [countable] an action done by a computer

flashcards.title: passing
flashcards.definition:
1 the passing of time the years the passing of time the years
the process of time going by
2 mention note something in passing mention note something in passing
if you say something in passing, you mention it while you are mainly talking about something else
3 the passing of something is the fact that it has ended
passing adjective
1 going past a place or person
2 passing days weeks years etc passing days weeks years etc
2 passing days weeks years etc passing days weeks years etc
4 a passing remark is one that you make while you are talking about something else
flashcards.example:
passing
â€¢ It may be difficult for the modern reader to grasp the emotional effect of his passing upon his people.
â€¢ His passing leaves a sore gap in his family circle and in his wider circle of friends and acquaintances.
â€¢ In passing, we can note that one proposal for spaceflight is to use the pressure of photons from the Sun.
â€¢ They lost the game partly because of ineffective passing.
â€¢ This resulted in the passing of the Consumer Protection Act 1987 which introduces a strict liability regime for defective products.
â€¢ Other parents equate education with the passing of examinations.
â€¢ the passing of the Cold War
â€¢ The passing of the Liverpool Corporation Act 1921 set the stage for inter-war policing.
â€¢ Animals walked there, the vibration of their passing stirring Tallis from her earthly sleep.



passing
â€¢ The malaise about a shared intellectual and literary culture was short-lived, the product of passing confrontation.
â€¢ Whether this is just a passing fad or a lasting fashion trend, only time will tell.
â€¢ passing fashions
â€¢ a passing glance
â€¢ Most people take only a passing interest in their horoscope.
â€¢ After all, Levi admits to more than a passing interest in things financial, shall we say.
â€¢ But only for one passing second.
â€¢ At the time, I didn't give Alison so much as a passing thought -- I had other things on my mind.
â€¢ Noise from the passing traffic could be heard from the backyard.
â€¢ Bernard reversed straight out of the new garage into the road and hit a passing van.
â€¢ Six-year-old Michael Smith and his parents were spotted by a passing yacht as they clung to a tiny buoyancy bag in darkness.

assing interest
â€¢ For all its emotional resonance, it was in my mind an issue of minor and passing interest.
â€¢ Yet caddis larvae, who do precisely that, command only passing interest.
â€¢ This was the brainchild of Martin and Hermon Bond, two farmers, who had more than a passing interest in golf.
â€¢ Anyway, it does no harm for a politician to evince some passing interest in sport.
â€¢ There were also rumours that newspaper tycoon Robert Maxwell was showing more than a passing interest in Storehouse.
â€¢ The backlash is awaited with interest by everyone, even those with only a passing interest in the music scene.
â€¢ After all, Levi admits to more than a passing interest in things financial, shall we say.
â€¢ As far as it goes, the film will be of passing interest to anybody acquainted with the myth.

flashcards.title: pick up
flashcards.definition:
1- lift something \someone up
2- pickup yourself up to get up the ground after you have fallen
3- tidy something to make a room or building tidy
4- get something
5- collect - pick up something â†” up to collect something from a place
6- Learn - pick something â†” up to learn something by watching or listening to other people
7- Notice to notice something that is not easy to notice, such as slight smell or a sign of something
8- Radio\signals if a machine picks up a sound, movement, or signal, it is able to notice it or receive it
9- Sex - to become friendly with someone you have just met because you want to have sex with them
10 - Start again
if you pick up where you stopped or were interrupt, you start again from that point
if you pick up an idea that has been mention, you return to it and develop it further
11- Improve
if a situation picks up, it improves
if a medicine or drink picks you up, it makes you feel better

flashcards.title: pocket
flashcards.definition:
1 IN CLOTHES a type of small bag in or on a coat, trouser etc that you can put money, key etc in
Luke came in with his hands in his pockets.
jacket/trouser etc pocket
The keys are in my trouser pocket.
pocket of
the inside pocket of his jacket
The policeman told me to turn out my pockets (=take everything out of them).
2 MONEY
the amount of money that you have to spend
There are eight hotels, with a price range to suit every pocket.
from/out of/into your own pocket
Dan had to pay for the repairs out of his own pocket.
He was accused of diverting some of the firmâ€™s money into his own pocket.
The deepening recession has hit peopleâ€™s pockets.
For investors with deep pockets (=a lot of money), the Berlin property market is attractive.
3 SMALL CONTAINER
a small bag or piece of material fasten to something so that you can put things into it
Please read the air safety card in the pocket of the seat in front.
4 SMALL AREA/AMOUNT
a small area or amount of something that is different from what surround it
pocket of
In some parts, there are still pockets of violence and unrest.
pockets of air inside the hull of the ship
5 be in somebody s pocket be in somebody s pocket
6 have something in your pocket have something in your pocket
7 out of pocket out of pocket
8 be live in each other s pockets be live in each other s pockets
9 GAME a small net on a pool, snooker, or billiard table, which you try to hit balls into
air pocket air pocket,
1 a current of air that makes a plane suddenly move down
2 a small area that becomes filled with air
burn a hole in your pocket,
if money burn a hole in your pocket, you want to spend it as soon as you can
line your own pockets,
to make yourself rich, especially by doing something dishonest â€“ used to show disapproval

pick somebody s pocket
to quietly steal something from someoneâ€™s pocket
Pocet Verb
1 to put something into your pocket
Maggie locked the door and pocketed the keys.
2 to steal money, especially money that you are responsible for
One inspector had pocketed up to $500,000 in bribes.
3 to get a large amount of money, win a prize etc, especially in a way that seems very easy or slightly dishonest
Johnston pocketed $2,500 in prize money.
4 to hit a ball into a pocket in the game of pool, snooker or billiards SYN pot

flashcards.title: positive
flashcards.definition:
1 ATTITUDE if you are positive about things, you are hopeful and confident, and think about what is good in a situation rather than what is bad OPP negative
positive about
Youâ€™ve got to be more positive about your work.
positive attitude/approach/outlook etc
Sheâ€™s got a really positive attitude to life.
the power of positive thinking
â€˜Think positive!â€™ she advised herself.
2 GOOD THING good or useful OPP negative
At least something positive has come out of the situation.
Write down all the positive things about your life.
The rural environment was having a positive effect on the childrenâ€™s health.
Itâ€™s been a very positive experience for her.
TV can be a positive influence.
the positive contribution to the community made by many older people
Itâ€™s been a difficult time but, on the positive side, I feel physically fine.
Women should be portrayed in a more positive light.
3 ACTION if you take positive action, you do something definite in order to try to achieve something
We need to take positive steps to improve the situation of families in poverty.
Positive action was required.
Itâ€™s a relief to know that something positive is being done.
4 SUPPORT expressing support, agreement, or approval OPP negative
positive response/reaction
The response weâ€™ve had from the public has been very positive.
Weâ€™ve had a lot of positive feedback from the people of this city.
positive about
Most people have been very positive about the show.
5 SURE [not before noun] very sure, with no doubt at all that something is right or true SYN certain
positive (that)
Are you absolutely positive you locked the door?
â€˜Are you sure about that?â€™ â€˜Positive.â€™
â–º see thesaurus at sure
6 SIGN showing that something is likely to succeed or improve
The fact that heâ€™s breathing on his own again is a positive sign.
7 positive proof/evidence/identification etc
8 SCIENTIFIC TEST showing signs of the medical condition or chemical that is being looked for OPP negative
The test results came back positive.
athletes who had tested positive for banned substances
children who are HIV positive
9 EMPHASIS [only before noun] spoken used to emphasize how good or bad something is SYN total
The journey was a positive nightmare.
10 NUMBER technical a positive number is more than zero OPP negative
11 ELECTRICITY technical having the type of electrical charge that is carried by protons OPP negative
a positive charge
[english)

flashcards.title: possession
flashcards.definition:
1 HAVING SOMETHING [uncountable] formal
if something is in your possession, you own it, or you have obtain it from somewhere
in somebodyâ€™s possession
The house has been in the familyâ€™s possession since the 1500s.
That information is not in our possession.
in possession of something
She was found in possession of stolen goods.
How did the painting come into your possession (=how did you get it)?
The finance company now has possession of the house.
We didnâ€™t take possession of (=get and start using) the car until a few days after the auction.
2 SOMETHING YOU OWN [countable usually plural]
something that you own or have with you at a particular time SYN belongings
He had sold all his possessions and left the country.
I packed my remaining possessions into the trunk.
treasured/prized/precious possession (=one that is very important to you)
This old violin had been her fatherâ€™s most treasured possession.
Prisoners were allowed no personal possessions.
3 CRIME [uncountable]
law the crime of having illegal drug or weapon with you or in your home
possession of
He was arrested and charged with possession of cocaine.
4 SPORT [uncountable]
when a person or team has control of the ball in some sport
win/lose/gain etc possession
Pittsburgh got possession and scored.
5 COUNTRY [countable usually plural]
a country controlled or govern by another country Franceâ€™s former colonial possessions
6 EVIL SPIRITS [uncountable] a situation in which someoneâ€™s mind is being controlled by something evil
Was it a case of demonic possession?
7 in full possession of your faculties senses in full possession of your faculties senses
able to think in a clear and intelligent way, and not crazy or affect by old age
8 possession is nine tenths of the law possession is nine tenths of the law
used to say that if you have something, you are likely to be able to keep it, even if it is not yours
[english)
flashcards.example:
possession
â€¢ Kortz was charged with theft and possession of stolen property.
â€¢ During their discussions, both had spoken of marriages that were held together first by children, and then by possessions.
â€¢ He had no drugs in his possession.
â€¢ On its next possession, Southern Utah turned the ball over on a pass out of bounds.
â€¢ Society without jealousy, greed, or possessions.
â€¢ Britain's former overseas possessions
â€¢ A small, terrified child clutching a satchel with both arms as though it were her most prized possession.
â€¢ They lost their home and all their possessions in the storm.
â€¢ In poor countries, children are the only way a family can increase their possessions.
take possession of
â€¢ I reminded him about the putter and took possession of it in the car park.
â€¢ The crawling and wriggling carcasses had been the innocent victims of the chaos taking possession of their world.
â€¢ At the end of April Gloucester took possession of the young king.
â€¢ He had taken possession of the castle by force.
â€¢ Whether or not a person has taken possession of land is a question of fact depending on all the particular circumstances.
â€¢ It is said that other Presidents without congressional authority have taken possession of private business enterprises in order to settle labor disputes.
â€¢ Immediately, however, a deadly languor took possession of her and she fell into a heavy sleep.
â€¢ They added up to the idea that he resented anyone placing a cross and trying to take possession of his territory.
personal possessions
â€¢ Water penetrated the two cabins, ran down the sides, gathered in pools, speckled droplets on clothing and personal possessions.
â€¢ You can extend it to cover any personal possessions that cost over Â£1,000 each or Â£3,500 in total.
â€¢ He is one of the few people I have ever met who has never been either inflated or deflated by personal possessions.
â€¢ Another reason for some optimism is the increase in personal possessions with which people enter the third age.
â€¢ She used the weekend of the Windsor Castle blaze to remove what little personal possessions she had left.
â€¢ Losses of personal possessions, money and items of kit inevitably took place at these spots.
â€¢ Other personal possessions include a Â£2,500 horse and a Â£25,000 Morgan car.
â€¢ Also there is the insurance to consider of your personal possessions and the contents of your home.
charged with possession
â€¢ He was taken straight to West Drayton police station and charged with possession of drugs.
â€¢ They're all in the nick. charged with possession.
win/lose/gain etc possession
â€¢ The match was finally settled two minutes into extra time when St Albans won possession in defence and broke quickly.
â€¢ The company also helps clients estimate, from memory, the value of lost possessions.
â€¢ Mason had blocked a layup attempt by Andre Miller with 16 seconds to play, setting up Seattle's winning possession.
â€¢ Rumour had it that Gaunt had poisoned his sister-in-law in order to gain possession of the whole of the inheritance.
â€¢ They will try to gain possession of the last piece of ground we possess.
â€¢ If you don't score you lose possession.
â€¢ Now after the changes if you do that and don't produce the ball then you lose possession.
colonial possessions
â€¢ A Zoological Society was founded in London in 1826 to act as a showcase for Britain's colonial possessions.

flashcards.title: pour
flashcards.definition:
1 LIQUID [transitive] to make a liquid or other substance flow out of or into a container by hold it at an angle
She poured coffee for everyone.
pour something into/out/down etc (something)
Pour the oil into a frying pan and heat.
pour something away (=get rid of something)
The wine was so bad I just poured it away.
pour somebody something
Why donâ€™t you pour yourself another drink?
2 LIQUID/SMOKE [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] if a lot of liquid or smoke pour out, it comes out from somewhere in very large amount
pour from/down/out
Smoke was pouring out of the upstairs windows.
Blood was pouring from his nose.
3 it pours it pours
to rain heavily without stop
Itâ€™s pouring now.
It poured all night.
4 PEOPLE OR THINGS [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] if a lot of people or things pour into or out of a place, a lot of them arrive or leave at the same time
pour into/out of/from etc
The crowds began pouring out of the stadium.
Offers of help poured in from all over the country.
5 LIGHT [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] if light is pouring into or out of a place, a lot of light is coming in or out
pour into/out of Light was pouring into the courtyard.
6 pour cold water over on something pour cold water over on something
7 pour scorn on somebody something pour scorn on somebody something
8 pour oil on troubled waters pour oil on troubled waters
9 pour it on pour it on
10 pour on the charm pour on the charm
[english)

flashcards.title: properly
flashcards.definition:
1 especially British English correctly, or in a way that is considered right SYN right American English
2 especially British English completely or fully SYN thoroughly
3 formal really
4 used to say that someone is right to do something SYN rightly
[english)
flashcards.example:
The brakes donâ€™t seem to be working properly.
Then heâ€™s not doing his job properly.
Parents should teach their children to behave properly in public.
properly trained staff

Is the chicken properly defrosted?
The allegations were never properly investigated.

Documents properly belonging to the family were taken away.

It isnâ€™t, properly speaking, a real science.

People are, quite properly, proud of their homes.

properly
â€¢ Surely manufacturers who offer these products and recommend them of use as a priming support for oils have done their research properly?
â€¢ He accused me of not doing my job properly.
â€¢ He questions whether the experiments were conducted properly.
â€¢ Keep on using lead free if the engine is not set properly after its recent service.
â€¢ Shamlou stood before her, and for the first time looked properly at his victim.
â€¢ Finding running shoes that fit properly can be tricky.
â€¢ Make sure the door is properly closed.
â€¢ The failure to treat Tamils properly has carried a fearsome price.
â€¢ It will take time to properly investigate the matter.
â€¢ In fact I damn nearly lost early on because I found it hard to concentrate properly on her defence strategy.
â€¢ However, the insurer probably will inspect the new house carefully, to be sure that it is properly retrofitted against earthquakes.
â€¢ For this reason any purchaser will wish to see that all documents in the chain of title are properly stamped.
â€¢ The company had failed to properly train their workers.

properly speaking
â€¢ But, even if not properly speaking a science, it is still worthy of systematic pursuit.
â€¢ A woman can not, properly speaking, desire at all.
â€¢ If knowledge, properly speaking, is knowledge of necessary causes, or real inner natures, then they are.

quite/very/perfectly properly
â€¢ I believe that until very recently it operated perfectly properly.
â€¢ The authority quite properly denies them the choice, and exercises it itself.
â€¢ In a functional department we face quite properly increasing pressure on our resources.
â€¢ They will be decided perfectly properly on the basis that the claims have been made.
â€¢ Mr Justice Douglas quite properly points out that the conspiracy before us is not a conspiracy to overthrow the Government.
â€¢ If proofs there are in this book they are only that Marxism is now quite properly the preserve of cranks and dreamers.
â€¢ But they are not satisfied beyond reasonable doubt so they decide, quite properly, to acquit of robbery.

flashcards.title: reach
flashcards.definition:
1 DEVELOPMENT [transitive] if someone or something reaches a particular point in their development or in a process or competition, they get to that point
Chelsea could reach the final of the European Cup.
reach the point/level/stage etc
I had reached the point where I was earning a good salary.
The kids have reached the age when they can care for themselves.
Register
In everyday English, people often use get to rather than reach:
The kids have got to the age where they can care for themselves.
2 RATE/AMOUNT [transitive] if something reaches a particular rate, amount etc, it increases until it is at that rate or amount
By 2008, that figure is expected to reach 7 million.
wind speeds reaching up to 180 mph Prices rose steadily to reach record levels.
3 AGREE [transitive] to agree on something or decide something after a lot of discussion or thought
reach a decision/agreement etc
The theatre has reached an agreement with striking actors.
It took the jury three days to reach a verdict.
The talks will continue until a conclusion is reached.
4 reach a target goal reach a target goal
5 TOUCH
a) [intransitive, transitive always + adverb / preposition ] to move your arm in order to touch or lift something with your hand
She reached into her bag and produced a business card.
He reached down to help her to her feet.
reach for
Kelly reached for his gun.
Luisa reached out her hand to stroke the cat.
b) [intransitive, transitive not in progressive]
to touch something by stretch out your arm
Itâ€™s no good â€“ I canâ€™t reach.
Sheâ€™s too small to reach the table.
c) [transitive] to get something from a high place by stretching up your arm
reach something down She fell while reaching down a vase from the top shel,.
6 LENGTH/HEIGHT [intransitive always + adverb/preposition, transitive not in progressive] to be big enough, long enough etc to get to a particular point
The phone lead isnâ€™t long enough to reach the bedroom.
a skirt that reaches halfway down her legs
reach as far as something/reach down to something
Her hair reaches down to her waist.
7 ARRIVE [transitive] to arrive at a place
We reached London late at night.
The pyramids can be reached by public transport
Register
In everyday English, people often use get to rather than reach:
We got to the airport just in time.
You can get to the pyramids by public transport.
8 SPEAK TO SOMEBODY [transitive] if you reach someone, you succeed in speaking to them on the telephone SYN contact
I can probably reach him on his mobile.
9 BE SEEN/HEARD [transitive] if a message, television programme etc reaches a lot of people, they hear it or see it Cable TV reaches a huge audience.
10 INFORMATION [transitive] if information reaches you, you hear about it
The news reached us in Lahore.
11 COMMUNICATE [transitive] to succeed in making someone understand or accept what you tell them SYN get through to
I just canâ€™t seem to reach Ed anymore.
12 reach for the stars reach for the stars
[)

flashcards.title: refuse
flashcards.definition:
1 [intransitive] to say firmly that you will not do something that someone has asked you to do
She asked him to leave, but he refused.
refuse to do something
The chairman refused to answer any more questions.
I absolutely refuse to take part in anything illegal.
flatly refuse/refuse point-blank (to do something)
(=refuse immediately and directly without giving a reason)
Mom flatly refused to go back into the hospital.
2 [intransitive, transitive] to say no to something that you have been offered SYN turn down
She refused a second piece of cake.
The offer seemed too good to refuse.
When they offered all that money, I could hardly refuse, could I? (=it was very unlikely that you would refuse)
3 [transitive] to not give or allow someone something that they want, especially when they have asked for it officially
refuse somebody something
She was refused a work permit.
[english)
flashcards.example:
THESAURUS
refuse to say firmly that you will not do something that someone has asked you to do

I asked the bank for a loan, but they refused.
When they refused to leave, we had to call the police.

say no spoken to say that you will not do something when someone asks you

They asked me so nicely that I couldnâ€™t really say no.

turn somebody/something down to https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/refuse to https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/accept an offer or https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/invitation, or a https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/formal https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/request

They offered me the job but I turned it down.
The board turned down a request for $25,000 to sponsor an art exhibition.
Iâ€™ve already been turned down by three colleges.

reject to refuse to accept an idea, offer, https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/suggestion, or planThey rejected the idea because it would cost too much money.

The Senate rejected a proposal to limit the program to two years.

decline formal to politely refuse to accept an offer or invitation, or refuse to do something

She has declined all offers of help.
A palace spokesman declined to comment on the rumours.

deny to refuse to allow someone to do something or https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/enter somewhere

They were denied permission to publish the book.
He was denied access to the US.

veto to officially refuse to allow a https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/law or plan, or to refuse to accept someoneâ€™s suggestion

Congress vetoed the bill.
The suggestion was quickly vetoed by the other members of the team.

disallow to officially refuse to accept something because someone has broken the https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/rule, or not done it in the https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/correct way

The goal was disallowed by the referee.
The court decided to disallow his evidence.

rebuff formal to refuse to accept someoneâ€™s offer, request, or suggestion

The company raised its offer to $6 billion, but was rebuffed.

He was politely rebuffed when he suggested holding the show in Dublin.

give somebody/something the thumbs down informal to refuse to allow or accept a plan or suggestion
The plan was given the thumbs down by the local authority.
They gave us the thumbs down.

flashcards.title: resolution
flashcards.definition:
1 DECISION [countable] a formal decision or statement agree on by a group of people, especially after a vote
pass/adopt/approve a resolution
The resolution was passed by a two-thirds majority.
a resolution calling for a ban on dumping nuclear waste
They have failed to comply with the resolution.
2 SOLUTION [singular, uncountable] when someone solve a problem, argument, or difficult situation
resolution of
a forum for the resolution of commercial disputes
3 PROMISE [countable] a promise to yourself to do something
resolveresolution to do something
Carol made a resolution to work harder at school.
New Yearâ€™s resolution (=a resolution made on January 1st)
4 DETERMINATION [uncountable] strong belief and determination
Then, with sudden resolution, she stood up.
5 CLEAR PICTURE [countable, uncountable] the power of a television, camera, microscope etc to give a clear picturehigh resolution (=how clear or unclear the picture is)
[)
flashcards.example:
COLLOCATIONS
VERBS

pass/approve a resolution
The Security Council passed a resolution condemning the countryâ€™s aggression.

adopt a resolution (=pass it)
The resolution was adopted by 12 votes to noun.

reject a resolution
The National Assembly rejected the resolution.

propose/introduce/put forward a resolution
The resolution was proposed by the chairman of the committee.

table a resolution (=officially propose it)
Siddall tabled a resolution asking for the Boardâ€™s approval of the Five Year Business Plan.

vote on a resolution
Are there any comments you wish to make before we vote on this resolution?

a resolution calling for something
We support the EU resolution calling for a ban on the use of these fishing nets.

a resolution condemning something
The UN Security Council tabled a resolution condemning the invasion.

flashcards.title: romance
flashcards.definition:
1 [countable] an exciting and often short relationship between two people who love each other affair
romance with
Hemingwayâ€™s romance with his nurse inspired him to write â€˜A Farewell to Armsâ€™.
Michelle married him after a whirlwind romance (=one that happens very suddenly and quickly).
holiday romance British English, summer romance American English (=one that happens during a holiday)
a short holiday romance
2 [uncountable] love, or a feeling of being in love
The romance had gone out of their relationship.
3 [uncountable] the feeling of excitement and adventure that is related to a particular place, activity etc
romance of
the romance of Hollywood
4 [countable] a story about the love between two people
romance novels
5 [countable] a story that has brave characters and exciting events
a Medieval romance
Romace Verb
1 [intransitive] to describe things that have happened in a way that makes them seem more important, interesting etc than they really were
romance about
an old man romancing about the past
2 [transitive] old-fashioned to try to persuade someone to love you
[english)
flashcards.example:
romance
â€¢ Evening is a good time for friendships and romance, but do not be too intense.
â€¢ Most married women surveyed said they were not victims of love at first sight and not moved to marriage by romance.
â€¢ The connection between ancient houses and mysteries of a shameful kind has its origin in Gothic romance.
â€¢ Some viewers objected to the interracial romance the show portrays.
â€¢ Invariably, romances form aboard the plane.
â€¢ My romance with Lois did not survive our high school graduation.

â€¢ It was a beautiful summer romance, but they knew it couldn't last.
â€¢ As the romance proceeded, she became restless.
â€¢ The romance of the movies was to a significant degree an entrepreneurial romance.
â€¢ the romance of life in the Wild West
â€¢ Richard and Penny had made no great secret of their romance, even though they were both married.
summer romance
â€¢ It was just a summer romance.
â€¢ Isabelle Pech pursued Richard Burley to Britain after he suddenly broke off their summer romance and disappeared.

flashcards.title: roundabout

1 a raised circular area where three or more roads join together and which cars must drive around SYN traffic circle American English

2 a round structure for children to play on in a park.

1 a roundabout way of saying something is not clear, direct, or simple SYN indirect OPP direct

The bus took a very long and roundabout route.

flashcards.title: rug
flashcards.definition:
1 a piece of thick cloth or wool that covers part of a f floor, used for warmth or as a decoration mat, carpet
2 British English a large piece of material that you can wrap around yourself, especially when you are travelling
3 pull the rug out from under somebody somebody s feet pull the rug out from under somebody somebody s feet
to suddenly take away something that someone was depend on to achieve what they wanted
4 a toupÃ© e â€“ used humorously
Rug Vs Carpet
he difference between a rug and a carpet seems to be how movable it is. What we call a carpet is a covering that stretches from wall to wall, affixed to the floor. On the other hand, rugs tend to be smaller than the room's square footage (by a lot or a little) and are not affixed to the floor. They can be rolled up and moved from place to place.

flashcards.title: rush
flashcards.definition:
Rushed
1 done very quickly or too quickly, because there was not enough time
We did have a meeting, but it was a bit rushed.
2 British English if you are rush, you are very busy because you have a lot of things to do quickly
Iâ€™ll talk to you later â€“ Iâ€™m a bit rushed at the moment.
Iâ€™ve been rushed off my feet (=extremely busy) all day.
Rush Verb
1 MOVE QUICKLY to move very quickly, especially because you need to be somewhere very soon
SYN hurry
A small girl rushed past her.
Mo rushed off down the corridor.
2 rush to do something rush to do something
to do something very quickly and without delay
I rushed to pack my suitcase before she came back.
He rushed to help his comrade.
3 DO SOMETHING TOO QUICKLY
to do or decide something too quickly, especially so that you do not have time to do it carefully or well
He does not intend to rush his decision.
rush into
Iâ€™m not rushing into marriage again.
rush through
She rushed through her script.
rush it/things
When we first met, neither of us wanted to rush things.
4 TAKE/SEND URGENTLY
to take or send someone or something somewhere very quickly, especially because of an unexpected problem
rush somebody/something to something
The Red Cross rushed medical supplies to the war zone.
Dan was rushed to hospital with serious head injuries.
5 MAKE SOMEBODY HURRY [transitive]
to try to make someone do something more quickly than they want to
Iâ€™m sorry to rush you, but we need a decision by Friday.
rush somebody into (doing) something
They felt they were being rushed into choosing a new leader.
6 LIQUID
if water or another liquid rush somewhere, it moves quickly
Water rushed through the gorge.
7 blood rushes to somebody s face cheeks blood rushes to somebody s face cheeks
used to say that someoneâ€™s face becomes red because they feel embarrass
I felt the blood rush to my face as I heard my name.
8 ATTACK [transitive]
to attack a person or place suddenly and in a group
They rushed the guard and stole his keys.
9 AMERICAN UNIVERSITIES American English
a) [transitive] to give parties for students, have meeting etc, in order to decide whether to let them join your fraternity or sorority (=type of club)
b) [intransitive, transitive] to go through the process of trying to be accepted into one of these club
10 AMERICAN FOOTBALL [intransitive, transitive] to carry the ball forward
rush2 â—â—â—‹ noun
1 FAST MOVEMENT [singular] a sudden fast movement of things or people
rush of air/wind/water
She felt a cold rush of air as she wound down her window.
in a rush
Her words came out in a rush.
At five past twelve there was a mad rush to the dinner hall.
2 HURRY [singular, uncountable] a situation in which you eed to hurry
I knew there would be a last-minute rush to meet the deadline.
Donâ€™t worry, thereâ€™s no rush. We donâ€™t have to be at the station until 10.
do something in a rush (=do something quickly because you need to hurry)
I had to do my homework in a rush because I was late.
be in a rush
Iâ€™m sorry, I canâ€™t talk now â€“ Iâ€™m in a rush.
3 the rush
4 PEOPLE WANTING SOMETHING [singular] a situation in which a lot of people suddenly try to do or get something
rush on
Thereâ€™s always a rush on swimsuits in the hot weather.
rush to do something
the rush to put computers in all schools
gold rush
5 FEELING [singular]
a) informal a sudden strong, usually pleasant feeling that you get from taking a drug or from doing something exciting high
The feeling of power gave me such a rush.
an adrenalin rush
b) rush of anger/excitement/gratitude etc a sudden very strong feeling of anger etc
I felt a rush of excitement when she arrived.
A rush of jealousy swept through her.
6 PLANT [countable usually plural] a type of tall grass that grows in water, often used for making baskets
7 rushes
8 AMERICAN STUDENTS [uncountable] American English the time when students in American universities who want to join a fraternity or sorority (=type of club) go to a lot of parties in order to try to be accepted
rush week

flashcards.title: scream
flashcards.definition:
Scream Verb
1 [intransitive] to make a loud high noise with your voice because you are hurt, frightened, excited etc SYN shriek
After the first few shots, people started screaming.
a screaming baby
scream with/in
She jumped to her feet, screaming in terror.
The children were screaming with laughter.
She was screaming her head off (=screaming a lot).
She began to scream blue murder (=scream very loudly).
He was dragged kicking and screaming to a nearby van.
2 [intransitive, transitive] (also scream out) to shout something in a very loud high voice because you are angry or frightened SYN yell
â€˜Get out!â€™ she screamed.
He screamed out her name.
scream for
I screamed for help.
scream at
He screamed at her to go away.
The crowd continued to scream abuse at him.
3 [intransitive] to make a very loud high noise
The police car approached, its siren screaming.
scream â—â—â— S3 noun
1 a loud high sound that you make with your voice because you are hurt, frightened, excited etc SYN shriek
We heard screams coming from the flat.
She saw the knife and let out a scream.
scream of laughter/terror etc
He fell back with a scream of terror and pain.
2 a very loud high sound
the scream of a jet taking off
3 a scream

flashcards.title: seed
flashcards.definition:
1 PLANTS
a) [countable, uncountable] a small hard object produced by plants, from which a new plant of the same kind grows
a packet of sunflower seeds
plant/sow seeds (=put them in the soil)
Sow the seeds one inch deep in the soil.
grow something from seed
We grew all our tomatoes from seed.
b) [uncountable] a quantity of seeds
Some of the poorest farmers donâ€™t have enough money to buy seed.
2 [countable] American English one of the small hard objects in a fruit such as an apple or orange, from which new fruit trees grow SYN pip British English
3 seeds of something
large number or quantity of something
4 go/run to seed
a) if a plant or vegetable goes or runs to seed, it starts producing flowers and seeds as well as leaves
b) if someone or something goes or runs to seed, they become less attractive or good, especially because they are getting old and have not been properly looked after
The old central bus station is going to seed.
5 number one/two/three etc seed
6 SEX [uncountable] biblical semen or sperm â€“ often used humorously
7 FAMILY [uncountable] biblical the group of people who have a particular person as their father, grandfather etc, especially when they form a particular race
seed Verb
1 [transitive] to remove seeds from fruit or vegetables
Add one lime, seeded and sliced.
2 [transitive] to give a player or team in a competition a particular position, according to how likely they are to win
be seeded 8th/18th etc
Sharapova was seeded fifth at Wimbledon.
3 [transitive] to plant seeds in the ground
a newly seeded lawn
4 [intransitive] to produce seeds
5 seed itself

flashcards.title: settle
flashcards.definition:
to end an argument or solve a disagreement
to decide what you are going to do, especially so that you can make definite arrangements
to go to place where no people have lived permanently before and start to live there
to put yourself or someone else in a comfortable position
to become quiet and calm or to make someone quiet and calm
[english)
flashcards.example:
settle
â€¢ Historians are unsure when the territory was first settled.
â€¢ The existing chimney's foundation has settled and needs to be replaced.
â€¢ However, he settled down again and, with his assistant Brunskill, continued to rule the gallows.
â€¢ I ask the House to settle down and listen to the questions.
â€¢ Blue resigns himself to a long wait and then settles down with his newspapers and magazines.
â€¢ The players need to have a chance to settle down.
â€¢ After her husband's death, Jackie went to the city to settle her husband's affairs.
â€¢ She settled herself by an oak tree on a hill overlooking the town
â€¢ The family settled in a small Nevada town where they opened a store.
â€¢ So that settles it. We'll pay you half the purchase price now, and the rest over two years.
â€¢ Before settling on a mandatory-guideline system, Congress considered other competing proposals for sentencing reform.
â€¢ A look of fury settled on his face.
â€¢ We talked to the carpenter to settle plans for the expansion of the restaurant.
â€¢ I settled the bill and left the restaurant.
â€¢ Last year the Department of the Environment was brought in to settle the case.
â€¢ In the end we settled the deal on very favorable terms.
â€¢ Once the question of the location of the state leper home was settled, the disease ceased to make headlines.
â€¢ Please settle this account within two weeks.
â€¢ Nothing is settled yet.
settle a dispute/lawsuit/conflict/argument etc
â€¢ It would be sensible for dioceses to establish procedures for arbitration in case these are needed to settle disputes.
â€¢ During 1975-9 they did settle disputes by threatening violence and by paying compensation, and said that this was customary.
â€¢ Wright State has settled a lawsuit filed by Ralph Underhill agreeing to pay the former basketball coach about $ 125,000.
â€¢ They're here to settle a dispute over whether or not to build a loo in the vestry of the fourteenth century church.
â€¢ Their father encouraged his sons to settle disputes with fists and arranged boxing matches at home.
â€¢ We will consult on a Lay Adjudicators scheme to make it easier for citizens to settle disputes with service providers.
â€¢ The tribunals were intended to provide a way for rural residents to settle disputes without legal formalities.
settle in
â€¢ It didn't take Charlie long to settle into his new job.
â€¢ Within a month she had settled into a moderate exercise regimen.
â€¢ Paul never really settled in at his last school.
â€¢ We normally give new employees a little while to settle in before we overload them with responsibilities.
settle yourself in/on etc something
â€¢ All three brothers had settled themselves in the area, Nathan's being a pleasant semi-detached residence of three storeys.
â€¢ At home the new Labour Government was settling itself in.
â€¢ Dry and fed, Ralph settled himself in front of the telephone.
â€¢ He settles himself on the roof.
â€¢ She settled herself in the driver's seat and held out her hand for the keys.
â€¢ So I settled myself in a small tavern just down the street.
â€¢ They settled themselves in a comer, both facing the door so that they had instant warning of anyone's approach.
settle... nerves
â€¢ Her hands had been clammy and her breathing irregular, but a small brandy had helped to settle her nerves.
â€¢ She breathed deeply, trying to settle her nerves.
â€¢ Lynn Bollington scored early on to settle the nerves and two Jo Green goals secured the win.
â€¢ Hignett then scored from the spot before Martijn Reuser settled the nerves of the East Anglian contingent.
settle on
â€¢ We watched as a butterfly settled on a branch near our window.
â€¢ Can we at least settle on a date for our next meeting?
â€¢ Hiroaki wanted white and I wanted black, so we settled on grey.
â€¢ We finally settled on Miami as the site of our next conference.
settle a bill/account/claim
â€¢ Officials can seize a home and sell it to settle a tax bill.
â€¢ Many Japanese companies settle their annual accounts at the end of March.
â€¢ It had set aside $ 24 million to settle claims by former managers that it had failed to pay required overtime.
â€¢ Cigarette-makers agreed in 1998 to pay the states $ 252 billion to settle claims for smoking-related health costs.
â€¢ You use them just like ordinary cheques here to settle bills or draw cash.
settle... affairs
â€¢ It aims to treat all taxpayers with equal fairness and to settle their tax affairs impartially.
settle over/on
â€¢ She settled on a one-pound sack of cookies for about $ 1.
â€¢ In the end she settled on a stiff dose of Courvoisier brandy poured straight into Lucy's mug.
â€¢ I settled on one of the gauges on the instrument panel in front of me.
â€¢ She had settled on the bottom with her bows more or less on a north-south line.
â€¢ I finally settled on the idea of studying pharmacy.
â€¢ When you are ready, fly down to Earth; settle on the moist green banks of a running stream.
â€¢ A sense of peace settled on the town's inhabitants.
â€¢ The meditation program he settled on was an Eastern breath-counting exercise.

flashcards.title: shore
flashcards.definition:
1 [countable, uncountable] the land along the edge of a large area of water such as an ocean or lake
We could see a boat about a mile from shore.
Only a few survivors reached the shore.
She began to swim to shore.
on the shores of something
a holiday resort on the shores of the Adriatic
on shore
We had a couple of hours on shore (=not on a ship).
off shore
The island is about three miles off shore (=away from the coast).
THESAURUS
shore
the area of sand, mud, or low land along the edge of the sea, a lake etc
I went down to the shore to meet him.
The fish is commonly found off the shores of Australia.
They had planned to take a picnic on the shores of Lake Havel.
coast
the land next to the sea
He lives on the Sussex coast.
one of the most luxurious hotels on the south coast
the Draugen oil field, off the West coast of Norway
the East Coast of the United States
beach
an area of sand or small stones at the edge of the sea
Let's go to the beach.
Brighton beach
the seashore
the land at the edge of the sea, consisting of sand or rocks
He walked with her along the seashore.
You can hear the waves breaking on the seashore.
the seaside British English the areas or towns next to the sea where people go to enjoy themselves
We went on day trips to the seaside.
Oh I do love to be beside the seaside (=a line from a well-known song).
a seaside town
a seaside resort
bank
the land along the side of a river
a journey along the banks of the River Ganges
He swam over to the other bank.
The river burst its banks.
the waterfront the part of a town or an area of land next to the sea, a river etc â€“ used especially when talking about buildings near the water
The restaurant is down on the waterfront.
a waterfront bar in Montreal called The Neptune
the waterside (also the lakeside, the riverside) the area at the edge of a lake, river etc
The mountains almost come down to the waterside.
a rented villa on the lakeside
A number of barges were hidden in the trees along the riverside.
beautiful riverside views
[english)

flashcards.title: shrank
flashcards.definition:
1 [intransitive, transitive] to become smaller, or to make something smaller, through the effects of heat or water
Iâ€™m worried about washing that shirt in case it shrinks.
pre-shrunk, shrunken
2 [intransitive, transitive] to become or to make something smaller in amount, size, or value OPP grow
The city continued to shrink.
shrink to
The firmâ€™s staff had shrunk to only four people.
Treatment can shrink a tumour.
We want to expand the business, not shrink it.
3 [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] to move back and away from something, especially because you are frightened
She listened, shrinking under the blankets, to their shouts.
Meredith was scared of him and shrank back.
His anger was enough to make the others shrink away from him.
shrink from something
shrink noun [countable] informal a psychoanalyst or psychiatrist â€“ used humorously

flashcards.title: shuttle flight
flashcards.definition:
An air shuttle is a scheduled airline service on short routes with a simplified fare and class structure.
[)
flashcards.example:
shuttle
â€¢ If I take the 6:30 shuttle, I'll be there in time for the meeting.
â€¢ Columbia blasted off Thursday on a planned 17-day flight, the longest ever for a shuttle.
â€¢ The cost of launching that ounce of gold into low-Earth orbit by shuttle would be about $ 830.
â€¢ Agents and ambassadors left on the down shuttle, frantically covering their tracks.
â€¢ The warp thread is wound round the pegs and two large and two small shuttles used for weaving the weft.
â€¢ A glorious bright turquoise liquid jersey pantsuit is the ultimate garb for travel by space shuttle.
â€¢ A daytime shuttle bus operates 6 days a week to the village.â€¢ The deployer mechanism snagged on a safety bolt, and the satellite never made it more than 850 feet from the shuttle.
â€¢ The shuttle also will nudge the observatory gently into a slighter higher orbit to extend its lifetime.
shuttle bus
â€¢ Private vehicles are prohibited in the area, which is served by a shuttle bus.
â€¢ Parmenter took the Agency shuttle bus back to Langley.
â€¢ The hotel is air-conditioned and offers a complimentary shuttle bus to the nearby Equador beach.
â€¢ A courtesy shuttle bus runs to and from the Ally Pally.
â€¢ C., will deploy a fuel cell-driven shuttle bus using methanol as a fuel.
â€¢ Use the free shuttle bus to the show.



shuttle
â€¢ A piston destined to shuttle back and forth within a cylinder will be made on a lathe.
â€¢ Ross watched as it shuttled between them, going from hand to hand across thirty feet of air.
â€¢ During the week, I often shuttle easily to appointments in central London by car.
â€¢ All day students are shuttled from room to room for forty two-to fifty five-minute periods of unrelated subject matter.
â€¢ The goldfish shuttled to and fro, beneath the flat leaves, and there was an hour longer for them to sit there.
â€¢ Passengers were herded onto buses and shuttled to hotels downtown.
shuttle between/back and forth
â€¢ Body bags were being zipped and trolleys shuttled back and forth.
â€¢ Now he had to devise a method by which workmen and supplies could shuttle back and forth across the gorge.
â€¢ We shuttle back and forth between the large department stores that anchor the mall.
â€¢ Pre-packed experiments will be shuttled back and forth from Earth and slotted into 13 research racks.
â€¢ Or does it merely shuttle back and forth like a ferry?
â€¢ Mrs Mandela has been shuttling back and forth with messages from her husband's prison home near Cape Town.
â€¢ A piston destined to shuttle back and forth within a cylinder will be made on a lathe.

flashcards.title: sight
flashcards.definition:
1 ABILITY TO SEE [uncountable] the physical ability to see SYN vision
Anneâ€™s sight is very good for someone of her age.
He began to lose his sight six years ago.
an emergency operation to save his sight
You will get a free sight test if you are under 16.
2 ACT OF SEEING [singular, uncountable] the act of seeing something
sight of
Just the sight of him made her go all weak.
at the sight of something
Marcie will faint at the sight of blood.
The house is hidden from sight behind trees.
3 THING YOU SEE [countable]
a) something you can see
familiar/common/rare etc sight
Street dentists are a common sight in Pakistan.
As he reached the front door, he saw a strange sight.
the sights and sounds of the forest
not a pretty sight, sorry sight(8)
b) the sights [plural] famous or interesting places that tourists visit
