flashcards.title: sink
flashcards.definition:
1 IN WATER [intransitive]
to go down below the surface of water, mud etc OPP float
Their motorboat struck a rock and began to sink.
The kids watched as the coin sank to the bottom of the pool.
The heavy guns sank up to their barrels in the mud.
2 BOAT [transitive]
to damage a ship so badly that it sinks
A luxury yacht was sunk in a bomb attack yesterday.
3 MOVE LOWER [intransitive]
to move downwards to a lower level
The sun was sinking behind the coconut palms.
Her chin sank onto her chest, and she looked despairing.
4 FALL/SIT DOWN [intransitive]
to fall down or sit down heavily, especially because you are very tired and weak
sink into/to/down/back etc
She let out a groan and sank into a chair.
He let go of her shoulders and she sank at once to the floor.
Marion sank down on a rock, and wept.
The minister sank to his knees (=he went down into a kneeling position) and prayed.
5 GET WORSE [intransitive always + adverb/preposition]
to gradually get into a worse condition
sink into
They lost all their money and sank into desperate poverty.
The good mood left me and I sank into depression.
The doctor said that the boy was sinking fast (=getting weaker and about to die).
6 your heart sinks
7 LOWER AMOUNT/VALUE [intransitive] to go down in amount or value SYN drop OPP rise
Shares in the company have sunk as low as 620p.
sink to
The population of the village sank to just a few families.
8 VOICE [intransitive]
written if your voice sinks, it becomes very quiet
sink to/into
Her voice sank to a whisper.
9 sinking feeling
10 be sunk
11 sink without trace
12 sink so low
13 USE SOMETHING SHARP [transitive] to put your teeth or something sharp into someoneâ€™s flesh, into food etc
sink something into something
The dog sank its teeth into my arm.
She sank her fork into the pie.
14 DIG INTO GROUND [transitive] if you sink something such as a well or part of a building, you dig a hole to put it into the ground
A well was sunk in the back garden, and water could be pumped up into the kitchen.
15 sink or swim
16 MONEY [transitive] to spend a lot of money on something
sink something in/into something
They sank their entire savings into their house.
17 BALL [transitive] to put a ball into a hole or basket in games such as golf or basketball
18 sink your differences
19 DRINK [transitive] British English informal to drink alcohol, especially in large quantities
We sank a few pints at the pub first.
sink Noun
a large open container that you fill with water and use for wash yourself, washing dish etc
basin Dirty plates were piled high in the sink.
[english)

flashcards.title: skid
flashcards.definition:
if a vehicle or a wheel on a vehicle skid, it suddenly slide sideways and you cannot control it
Skid noun
1 SLIDING MOVEMENT a sudden sliding movement of a vehicle that you cannot control
Turn the car towards the skid if you lose control of it.
He slammed on the brakes and we went into a long skid (=started to skid).
2 on the skids
3 put the skids under something
4 SPORT [usually singular] American English a period of time during which a person or team is not successful â€“ used in news reports
The Red Sox victory ended a six-game skid.
5 AIRCRAFT a flat narrow part that is under some aircraft such as helicopters, and is used in addition to wheels for landing
6 USED TO LIFT/MOVE [usually plural] a piece of wood that is put under a heavy object to lift or move it
[english)

skid on/into/across etc

flashcards.title: smooth
flashcards.definition:
1 SURFACE
a smooth surface has no rough parts, lump, or hole, especially in a way that is pleasant and attractive to touch OPP rough
2 HAPPENING WITHOUT PROBLEMS
happening or operating successfully, without any problems
3 MOVEMENT [only before noun] with no sudden movements or changes of direction, especially in a way that is graceful or comfortable
4 PERSON someone who is smooth is polite, confident, and relaxed, but is often not sincere
5 LIQUID MIXTURE a liquid mixture that is smooth has no big pieces in it OPP lumpy
6 SOUND a voice or music that is smooth is soft and pleasant to listen to
7 TASTE a drink such as wine, coffee, whisky, or beer that is smooth is not bitter but tastes pleasant
Smooth Verb
1 to make something such as cloth or hair flat by moving your hands across it
2 (also smooth down) to make a rough surface flat and even
3 [always + adverb/preposition] to rub a liquid, cream etc gently over a surface or into a surface
[english)
flashcards.example:
Her skin felt smooth and cool.
a smooth pebble
The stone steps had been worn smooth.

Sarah is responsible for the smooth running of the sales department.
The new government has promised a smooth transition of power.

Swing the tennis racket in one smooth motion.
The jet made a smooth landing.

It wasnâ€™t a very smooth ride.

a smooth salesman
He was a smooth talker.
George is a smooth operator (=someone who does things in a smooth way).

Beat the eggs and flour until they are smooth.

smooth jazz
He has one of those silky smooth (=very smooth) voices.

a smooth full-bodied wine

Liz smoothed her skirt and sat down.
smooth something back/down
She smoothed back her hair.


The wood was smoothed and trimmed to size. Smooth down all the surfaces before you start painting.

She smoothed suntan lotion over her legs.


smooth
â€¢ Across the table, Tanya smoothed down her skirt and looked at her watch.
â€¢ Luce washed herself and smoothed her fringe as best she could, scowling at her reflection in the mirror.
â€¢ She stood up, a little unsteadily, and smoothed her frock.
â€¢ She removed her cap and smoothed her lush black hair.
â€¢ He would sit, smoothing his pants, and wait.
â€¢ But Internet sales are being delayed until kinks can be smoothed out, as well as security issues.
â€¢ The curiously but hopefully not phonetically named Botox is injected into the forehead to smooth out the skin.
â€¢ Every morning she smoothes the bedclothes out and dusts the room.
â€¢ He smooths the circle to the exact depth required and marks it with a big cross.
â€¢ He wanted to smooth the web of hair that spilled down her back springing alive from the bones of her head.

1 very wet or wearing very wet clothes SYN drenched

blood-soaked/oil-soaked etc
his blood-soaked clothes

soaked

â€¢ Panting and soaked with sweat, Ron came running into the house.
got soaked

Example: "There was a spark of hope in her eyes."
An electrical discharge:
A flash that results when electricity jumps between two points.
Example: "The spark from the wire shocked him."
A trigger or catalyst:
Something that causes a larger event to begin.

flashcards.title: spill
flashcards.definition:
1 [intransitive, transitive] if you spill a liquid, or if it spills, it accidentally flow over the edge of a container pour
Katie almost spilled her milk.
spill something down/on/over something
Oh no! Iâ€™ve spilt coffee all down my shirt!
spill on/over etc
He slipped and the wine spilled all over the carpet.
2 [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] if people or things spill out of somewhere, they move or fall out in large numbers SYN pourspill out/into/onto etc
Crowds from the theatre were spilling onto the street.
3 spill the beans spill the beans
to tell something that someone else wanted you to keep a secret
â€¢ "Does Phillip know about our plan?" "yes someone must have spilled the beans."
â€¢ You know, spill the beans.
4 spill your guts spill your guts
to tell someone all about your private life, or about a personal secret
â€¢ rob let Al talk until he finally spilled his guts about his affair with Louise.
â€¢ Albert let Rob run on till he spilled his guts, but Loulse probe.
5 spill blood spill blood
to kill or wound people
cry over spilt milk
to waste time feeling sorry about an early mistake or problem that cannot be changed Itâ€™s
no use crying over spilt milk.
spill into onto spill into onto
spill over spill over
[english)
flashcards.example:
spill
â€¢ A tanker has run aground, spilling 60,000 gallons of oil into the sea.
â€¢ Aaron spilled all the popcorn on the floor.
â€¢ People spill back across the empty space of moonlight, and the dancers' faces merge with the crowd.
â€¢ Q.. The oil man spilled heating oil on light-gray semitransparent stained clapboards.
â€¢ I had to handle it carefully to keep from spilling it on myself.
â€¢ Careful - you'll spill it!
â€¢ I almost spilled my coffee.
â€¢ Oops, I just spilled my water.
â€¢ Such conflicts spilled over into the immediate postwar phase.
â€¢ There are also times when we allow conflicts away from work to spill over into the workplace and harm our careers.
â€¢ Someone had spilled red wine all over the carpet.
â€¢ "How was the party?" "OK, but some idiot spilled wine all over my new dress."
spill on/over etc
â€¢ And the emotion surrounding this year's event spilled over.
â€¢ Drop a couple of marbles into the cup and watch the water spill over.
â€¢ He also said a 2,000-gallon oil spill on Harbor Island in Seattle had been contained on land.
â€¢ But referee Ed Morrison's leniency led to bad blood spilling over in a six-man brawl as Richards looked for revenge.
â€¢ Guilt Guilt is an unwanted feeling that frequently spills over into behaviour.
â€¢ The Turtle moves through the 11-foot mark in town and spills over its banks.
â€¢ In another moment, blood is being spilled on the corporate carpets as a ticket manager named Andrew Follon is fired.
â€¢ Moments later, they swung open, spilling over with an abundance to feed all who were hungry.
spill out/into/onto etc
â€¢ Then he gently shook the urn, so that the contents would spill out.
â€¢ Today, many stores have facades that look like tourist shops anyway, the goods spilling on to the sidewalks.
â€¢ The sense of violence and anger, together with passionate interest, spilled out all over the place.
â€¢ The facts, which spilled out in no particular order, revealed the flip side of the fairytale.
â€¢ When we spilled out into the street a few minutes later, it was in a kind of glow.
â€¢ The questions spilled out of her.
â€¢ By Friday morning, trash is spilling out of the cans and on to the ground.
â€¢ In summer the family spills out on to an adjoining sun-trap patio.

flashcards.definition:

staff of 10/50 etc

They employ a total of 150 staff.
The staff were very helpful.
medical/academic/library etc staff
a strike by ambulance staff
one of our longest-serving staff members
member of staff British English
Iâ€™d like to welcome a new member of staff.
on the staff (of something)

flashcards.title: stamp
flashcards.definition:
1 MAIL (also postage stamp formal) a small piece of paper that you buy and stick onto an envelope or package before posting it
a 29-cent stamp
Richard collects stamps.
a second-class stamp
2 a tool for pressing or printing a mark or pattern onto a surface, or the mark made by this tool
a date stamp
a passport stamp
3 the stamp of something
4 PAYMENT British English a small piece of paper that is worth a particular amount of money and is bought and collected for something over a period of time
television licence stamps
5 TAX British English a piece of paper for sticking to some official papers to show that British tax has been paid
6 of... stamp
7 WITH FOOT an act of stamping, especially with your foot
an angry stamp
Seed Verb
1 PUT FOOT DOWN [intransitive, transitive] to put your foot down onto the ground loudly and with a lot of force
The audience stamped and shouted.
â€˜I will not!â€™ Bert yelled and stamped his foot (=because he was angry).
She stood at the bus stop stamping her feet (=because she was cold).
stamp on somebody/something (=try to hurt or kill someone or something, by putting your foot down onto them)
Marta shrieked and started stamping on the cockroach.
2 WALK NOISILY [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] to walk somewhere in a noisy way by putting your feet down hard onto the ground because you are angry SYN stomp
stamp around/out of/off etc
My mother stamped off down the stairs.
3 MAKE A MARK [transitive] to put a pattern, sign, or letters on something, using a special tool
The woman at the desk stamped my passport.
Among the papers was a brown folder stamped â€˜SECRETâ€™.
stamp something on something
Stamp the date on all the letters.
4 AFFECT SOMEBODY/SOMETHING [transitive] to have an important or permanent effect on someone or something
The experience remained stamped on her memory for many years.
stamp somebody with something
His army years had stamped him with an air of brisk authority.
5 MAIL [transitive] to stick a stamp onto a letter, parcel etc
stamp somebody as something
stamp on somebody/something
stamp something â†” out
See Verb table

flashcards.title: steal
flashcards.definition:
1 TAKE SOMETHING [intransitive, transitive] to take something that belongs to someone else
Boys broke into a shop and stole Â£45 in cash.
steal from
He stole money from his parents.
steal something from somebody/something
Heâ€™d stolen the flowers from our garden.
2 USE IDEAS [intransitive, transitive] to use someone elseâ€™s ideas without getting permission or without admitting that they are not your own ideas SYN pinch
Inventors know that someone is always going to try to steal their designs.
steal something from somebody
A well-known scientist was accused of stealing ideas from his former student.
3 MOVE SOMEWHERE [intransitive always + adverb/preposition] to move quietly without anyone noticing you SYN creep
steal into/across etc
He dressed quietly and stole out of the house.
4 steal the show/limelight/scene
5 steal a look/glance etc
6 SPORT
a) [intransitive, transitive] to run to the next base before someone hits the ball in the sport of baseball
b) [transitive] to suddenly take control of the ball, puck etc when the other team had previously had control of it, for example in basketball or ice hockey
Roy steals the ball four times in the first half.

flashcards.title: steam
flashcards.definition:
noun Steam
1- GAS the hot mist that water produce when it is boiled
2- Mist on surface the mist that forms on windows, mirrors etc when warm wet air suddenly become cold
3- power power that is produces by boiling water to make steam, in order to make thing work or move
4- Railway a railway system in which the trains use steam for power
Verb Steam
1- if something steams, steam rises from it, especially because it is hot
2- to cook something in steam
3- to travel somewhere in a boat or train that uses steam to produce power
4- to go somewhere very quickly
[english)
flashcards.example:
1- steam rose from the hot tub
3- the engines are driven by steam
8- the age of steam


steam
â€¢ There was a smell in the air, hot metal, chemical steam.
â€¢ Who else but Galwey should arrive full steam at his shoulder, outpacing even Simon Geoghegan in his hunger for the ball.
â€¢ However, in midafternoon New York trading, the rally lost steam.
â€¢ It was recreation hour, explained Brother Andrew with a smile, and the Brothers were letting off steam.
â€¢ The water was just right, slid over his skin as he gave out a long low satisfied moan into the steam.
steam engine/train/hammer etc

â€¢ Coal for the mill's steam engine was carried up the steep hill on donkeys.
â€¢ The immense surrogate slave power released by the steam engine ushered in the Industrial Revolution.

flashcards.title: stick
flashcards.definition:
1 ATTACH [intransitive, transitive] to attach something to something else using a substance, or to become attached to a surface
stick something on/to/in etc something
Someone had stuck posters all over the walls.
stick to/together
I could feel my shirt sticking to my back.
The oil keeps the pasta from sticking together.
This stamp wonâ€™t stick properly.
2 PUSH IN [intransitive, transitive always + adverb/preposition] if a pointed object sticks into something, or if you stick it there, it is pushed into it
stick (something) in/into/through something
pins stuck in a notice board
The boy stuck his finger up his nose.
3 PUT [transitive always + adverb/preposition] informal to put something somewhere quickly and without much care SYN bung
Just stick it in the microwave for a few minutes.
The cards had been stuck through the letterbox.
â–º see thesaurus at put
4 MOVE PART OF BODY [transitive always + adverb/preposition] if you stick a part of your body somewhere, you put it in a position where other people can see it SYN put
Clara stuck her head around the door to see who was there.

flashcards.title: stitch
flashcards.definition:
1 sewing a short piece of thread that has been sewn into a piece of cloth or action of the thread going into and out of the cloth
2- for wound: a piece of special thread which used to sew the edges of a wound together
3- pain: a sharp pain in the side of your body, which you can get by running or laugh a lot
4- with wool: a small circle of wool that is formed around a needle when you are knit
5- style: a particular way of sewing or knitting that makes a particular pattern
[english)
flashcards.example:
stitch
â€¢ Sandstrom needed 10 stitches to close a cut on his forehead.
â€¢ After jogging about a mile, I suddenly got a stitch in my side.
â€¢ She showed me how to cover the cloth with an embroidery stitch which finally created a small, neat, round button.
â€¢ Picture by Brendan O'Sullivan Few of us get through childhood without a broken bone or a few stitches.
â€¢ This allowed four stitches between hedgehogs if they were knitted as a band or series of bands on a sweater.
â€¢ After the last stitch of the row, bring the needle up through the stitch above.
â€¢ Most start with a welt and then change to the main stitch and there may even be some shaping to do.
â€¢ The seam of the shirt was straight and the stitches tight and regular.
â€¢ The Toronto Sun reported that she received two stitches, but neither the Rangers nor the hospital would confirm that.

very close to something
8 be made of stone be made of stone

flashcards.title: strange
flashcards.definition:
1 unusual or surprising, especially in a way that is difficult to explain or understand SYN odd
2 someone or something that is strange is not familiar because you have not seen or meet them before
[english)
flashcards.example:
THESAURUS
strange unusual or surprising, especially in a way that is difficult to understand, or that is a little frightening

Whatâ€™s that strange noise downstairs?
Thatâ€™s strange â€“ Iâ€™m sure I left my keys on the table.
a strange old man

funny/odd especially spoken a little strange and making you feel slightly surprised or worried



Thereâ€™s a funny smell in the kitchen.
Itâ€™s odd that you canâ€™t remember him at all.

curious especially written strange, especially in an interesting way. Curious is a little more formal than strange

a curious fact
Thereâ€™s something rather curious about small-town America.
She remembered curious little details.

mysterious strange â€“ used about something that people know little about and are unable to explain or understand

He had disappeared in mysterious circumstances.
There were reports of mysterious lights in the sky.

eccentric strange in a way that seems slightly crazy and amusing â€“ used about people and their behaviour

He lived completely alone and had some slightly eccentric habits.
an eccentric old lady

peculiar slightly strange, and different from what you would normally expect â€“ used especially when this is either amusing or worrying

She sometimes wears rather peculiar clothes.
He had a peculiar expression on his face.

VERY STRANGE
weird very strange or very different from what you are used to

I had a weird dream last night.
Itâ€™s a weird and wonderful place.

bizarre extremely strange and different from what is usually considered normal

It was a bizarre situation.
Markâ€™s behaviour was really bizarre.

surreal extremely strange and unconnected with real life or normal experiences, like something out of a dream

His paintings are full of surreal images.
There is something surreal about the climate change talks in Bali.
The plantâ€™s flowers were so big that they seemed almost surreal

uncanny very strange â€“ used especially about someone having an unusual ability to do something, or looking surprisingly similar to someone

mysterious strange â€“ used about something that people know little about and are unable to explain or understand

eccentric strange in a way that seems slightly crazy and amusing â€“ used about people and their behaviour

peculiar slightly strange, and different from what you would normally expect â€“ used especially when this is either amusing or worrying

flashcards.title: Strap
flashcards.definition:
a narrow band of strong material that is used to fasten, hang, or hold onto something
a bra strap
The strap of my bag is broken.
verb
1 [always + adverb/preposition] to fasten something or someone in place with one or more strap
strap something on/down etc
He was only ten when he strapped on a guitar for the first time.
soldiers with grenades strapped to their belts
be strapped in (=have a belt fastened around you in a car)
Are the kids strapped in?
2 British English (also strap up) to tie bandages firmly round a part of your body that has been hurt
Grammar
Strap is often used in the passive.

flashcards.title: take-up
flashcards.definition:
1 take something â†” up
to become interested in a new activity and to spend time doing it
Roger took painting up for a while, but soon lost interest.
2 take something up
to start a new job or have a new responsibility
Peter will take up the management of the finance department.
take up a post/a position/duties etc
The headteacher takes up her duties in August.
3 take something â†” up if you take up a suggestion, problem, complaint etc, you start to do something about it
Now the papers have taken up the story.
take something â†” up with
The hospital manager has promised to take the matter up with the member of staff involved.
I am still very angry and will be taking it up with the authorities.
4 take up something
to fill a particular amount of time or space
be taken up with something
The little time I had outside of school was taken up with work.
take up space/room
old books that were taking up space in the office
5 take something â†” up to accept a suggestion, offer, or idea
Rob took up the invitation to visit.
take up the challenge/gauntlet
Rick took up the challenge and cycled the 250-mile route alone.
6 take up something to move to the exact place where you should be, so that you are ready to do something
The runners are taking up their positions on the starting line.
7 take something â†” up to make a piece of clothe shorter OPP let down
8 take something â†” up to continue a story or activity that you or someone else had begun, after a short break
Iâ€™ll take up the story where you left off.
[english)
flashcards.example:
take up a post/a position/duties etc
â€¢ One eye shifts right round the body so that it takes up a position alongside the other.
â€¢ Edward took up a position at the door-post.
â€¢ I took up a position in a university library after a career break.
â€¢ The I in enunciating a signifying chain signifies the self by taking up a position in the signifying chains enunciated.
â€¢ The strong Auckland group within the team took up a position of influence.
â€¢ Robert took up a position on the boundary, fairly near to the maths master.
â€¢ Then she took up a position standing right at the back.
â€¢ In addition, Lacan feels that taking up a position with respect to meaning structures is inextricably gender-linked.
take the matter up
â€¢ When Parliament returned, the Opposition would take the matter up and proceed to a vote of censure.
â€¢ I told him the President should take the matter up directly with the First Lady.
â€¢ I recommend that the hon. Gentleman take the matter up with his council.
â€¢ She was furious, denied everything and said her husband would be taking the matter up with my editor.
â€¢ Should a student have any security problems, he/she should take the matter up with Security Staff.
â€¢ Male speaker I can and shall take the matter up with the Attorney General in relation to the sentence which has been past.
â€¢ I am going to take the matter up with the company to try to save the jobs for Worcester.
â€¢ If not you can take the matter up with their manager.
take up space/room
â€¢ And all that good seaweed I collected just sits in a bag in the cupboard, taking up space.
â€¢ I mean, they take up space and so on, they need dusting.
â€¢ But the brain is surrounded by the skull, and all that escaped blood takes up space, squeezing the brain.
â€¢ She believes that it was wrong of her to take up space within her school.
take up the challenge/gauntlet
â€¢ Ability Franchisees come from all sorts of backgrounds, with women increasingly taking up the challenge.
â€¢ If you are dissatisfied it is your responsibility to determine why and to take up the challenge.
â€¢ Johnson gleefully took up the challenge.
â€¢ If the profession does not take up the challenge others will, and an opportunity will have been missed.
â€¢ If human beings took up the challenge, their response would lay the foundations of civilization.
â€¢ He has taken up the challenge to lead.
â€¢ As it stands, few serious runners are likely to take up the challenge to turn it on.
taking up... positions
â€¢ Out we went at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, taking up our positions as dusk arrived.
â€¢ Reader Activity My interviewees are taking up subject positions as readers as they talk to me.
â€¢ Taking up Positions as Readers Knowledge of the ways in which texts circulate colours reading.

flashcards.title: temper
flashcards.definition:
1 [countable, uncountable] a tendency to become angry suddenly or easily
That temper of hers will get her into trouble one of these days.
According to Nathan, Robin has quite a temper.
Theo needs to learn to control his temper.
quick/bad/fiery etc temper
Be careful, heâ€™s got a pretty violent temper.
tempers flare (also tempers become frayed British English) (=people become angry)
Masonâ€™s temper flared when he spotted his girlfriend kissing another man.
2 lose your temper
3 [singular, uncountable] the way you are feeling at a particular time, especially when you are feeling angry for a short time
in a temper
Itâ€™s no use talking to him when heâ€™s in a temper.
Pete hit his brother in a fit of temper.
be in a bad/foul temper (=to be angry)
Watch out â€“ sheâ€™s been in a foul temper all day.
fly into a temper
Her boss would fly into a temper if a project wasnâ€™t done on time.
4 keep your temper
to stay calm when it would be easy to get angry
I was finding it increasingly difficult to keep my temper.
5 good-tempered/foul-tempered/quick-tempered etc
6 [singular] formal the general attitude that people have in a particular place at one time
temper of
the temper of life in Renaissance Italy

flashcards.title: thin
flashcards.definition:
1 NOT THICK
if something is thin, there is only a small distance between its two opposite sides or surfaces
OPP thick
a thin gold chain
Sheâ€™s only wearing a thin summer jacket (=a jacket made of light material).
two thin slices of bread
The road was covered with a thin layer of ice.
The skin on the eyelids is the thinnest on the body.
paper/wafer thin
(=very thin)
Keep your voice down â€“ the walls are paper thin.
2 NOT FAT
having little fat on your body OPP fat
He was tall and thin, with short brown hair.
thin arms/legs/lips etc
He has long thin hands.
Most high school girls say they want to be thinner.
as thin as a rake / rail / whippet (=very thin)
3 HAIR if someone has thin hair, they do not have a lot of hair
a thin straggly beard
His hair is quite thin on top.
4 LIQUID a liquid that is thin flow very easily because it has a lot of water in it OPP thick
thin paint
5 SMOKE/MIST smoke or mist that is thin is easy to see through OPP thick
The fog is quite thin in places.
6 AIR air that is thin is more difficult to breathe than usual because it has less oxygen in it the thinner air high in the mountains
7 EXCUSE/ARGUMENT/EVIDENCE ETC
a thin excuse, argument, or evidence is not good or detail enough to be useful or effective
Evidence that capital punishment deters crime is pretty thin.
8 a thin margin/majority etc
a very small number or amount of something
Engle beat Blanchard by a razor-thin margin (=a very small number of votes) in the race for governor.
9 SMILE a thin smile does not seem very happy or sincere
Charlie gave her a thin smile.
10 VOICE/SOUND a thin voice or sound is high and unpleasant to listen to
His thin voice trailed off.
11 the thin end of the wedge the thin end of the wedge
12 be thin on the ground be thin on the ground
13 be having a thin time of it be having a thin time of it
14 be walking treading skating on thin ice be walking treading skating on thin ice
15 disappear vanish into thin air disappear vanish into thin air
16 out of thin air out of thin air

flashcards.title: thought
flashcards.definition:
the past tense and past participle of think
1 SOMETHING YOU THINK ABOUT [countable] something that you think of, remember, or realize SYN idea

2 thoughts thoughts
3 CAREFUL CONSIDERATION [uncountable] careful and serious consideration
With more thought and care this would have been a first-class essay.
give something thought/give thought to something (=think carefully about something)
Iâ€™ve been giving your proposal a lot of thought.

4 ACT OF THINKING [uncountable] the act or process of thinking
lost/deep in thought
(=thinking so much that you do not notice what is happening around you)
Derek was staring out of the window, lost in thought.

5 CARING ABOUT SOMETHING [countable, uncountable] a feeling of worry or caring about something
thought for
He went back into the burning building with no thought for his own safety.

6 INTENTION [countable, uncountable] intention or hope of doing something
thought of doing something
I had no thought of gaining any personal advantage.
Lucy gave up all thought of finishing the essay that day.
7 WAY OF THINKING [uncountable] a way of thinking that is typical of a particular group, period of history etc
ancient Greek/feminist/18th-century etc thought

flashcards.title: through
flashcards.definition:
1 DOOR/PASSAGE ETC
into one side or end of an entrance, passage, hole etc and out of the other side or end
She smiled at him as he walked through the door.
Water will be pumped through a pipe.
I managed to squeeze through a gap in the hedge.
They were suddenly plunged into darkness as the train went through a tunnel.
There were people standing in the doorway and I couldnâ€™t get through.
through to
I went through to the kitchen to see who was there.
2 CUTTING/BREAKING
cutting or breaking something, or making a hole from one side of it to the other
A football came crashing through the window.
straight/right/clean through
The bullet passed straight through his skull.
3 ACROSS AN AREA from one side of an area to the other or between a group of things
We passed through France on our way to Italy.
We made our way through the village to the farm.
The wind howled through the trees.
He had to push his way through the crowd to get to her.
Let me through â€“ Iâ€™m a doctor.
get through/make it through (=reach a place after a difficult journey)
Youâ€™ll never get through â€“ the snowâ€™s two metres deep.
Rescue teams have finally made it through to the survivors.
We drove right through the town centre.
Carry on straight through the village.
4 SEE THROUGH SOMETHING if you see something through glass, a window etc, you are on one side of the glass etc and it is on the other
I could see her through the window.
I could see right through the thin curtains.
5 PAST A PLACE past a place where you are suppose to stop
It took us ages to get through passport control.
He drove straight through a red light.
6 TIME during and to the end of a period of time
The cold weather continued through the spring.
He slept right through the day.
The fighting went on all through the night.
7 PROCESS/EXPERIENCE from the beginning to the end of a process or experience
The book guides you through the whole procedure of buying a house.
When you have been through a terrible experience like that, it takes a long time to recover.
Itâ€™s a miracle that these buildings came through the war undamaged.
8 COMPETITIONS past one stage in a competition to the next stage
through to
This is the first time theyâ€™ve ever made it through to the final.
They didnâ€™t even get through the first round of the contest.
9 BECAUSE OF SOMETHING because of something
How many working days were lost through sickness last year?
10 BY MEANS OF SOMETHING/SOMEBODY by means of a particular method, service, person etc
She got her first job through an employment agency.
a success that was achieved through co-operative effort and wise leadership
I heard about it through a friend.
11 PARLIAMENT/CONGRESS
if a proposal passes through a parliament, it is agreed and accepted as a law
A special bill was rushed through Congress to deal with the emergency.
12 may through june wednesday through friday etc may through june wednesday through friday etc
13 halfway through something halfway through something
14 TELEPHONE British English connect to someone by telephone
I tried phoning you, but I couldnâ€™t get through.
Please hold the line and Iâ€™ll put you through.
through to
Did you manage to get through to her?
15 wet through cooked through etc wet through cooked through etc
16 through and through through and through
17 through to london paris etc through to london paris etc
18 get go run through something get go run through something
[english)
[through | meaning of through in Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English | LDOCE](through)
flashcards.example:
through
â€¢ He bought the tickets through a friend at the stadium.
â€¢ Rabbits got into the backyard through a hole in the fence.
â€¢ The bill's passage through Congress was not a smooth one.
â€¢ Fill out this form before you pass through customs.
â€¢ The bullet had passed through his right arm.
â€¢ Hundreds of working days have been lost this year through illness.
â€¢ The Community Association collapsed through lack of support.
â€¢ Prices are generally lowest from January through March and highest June through August.
â€¢ The store is open Monday through Saturday.
â€¢ It was through sheer laziness that we didn't get our flight booked on time.
â€¢ "When will you be away?" "The 17th through the 19th."
â€¢ The two men fled through the back door and escaped from police.
â€¢ Over the weekend, we took a leisurely drive through the countryside.
â€¢ Janet needed a lot of support to make it through the death of her husband.
â€¢ As the water passes through the filter, dirt is taken out.
â€¢ Through the kitchen window, I saw the mailman walking up to the house.
â€¢ The party continued through the night until dawn.
â€¢ It will be several months before your newborn sleeps through the night.
â€¢ The driver had gone straight through the traffic lights and hit an oncoming car.
â€¢ Rescue workers searched through the wreckage for survivors.
through to
â€¢ Something is preventing the gas from flowing through to the engine.
straight/right/clean through
â€¢ Jen woke me up around eight that night, asking if I was going to sleep straight through.

Defenition: 1Â DOOR/PASSAGE ETCÂ 
into one side or end of an https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/entrance, https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/passage,Â https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/hole etc and out of the other side or endÂ 

She smiled at him as he walked through the door.
Water will be pumped through a pipe.Â 
I managed to squeeze through a gap in the hedge.
They were suddenly plunged into darkness as the train went through a tunnel.
There were people standing in the doorway and I couldnâ€™t get through.
through toÂ 
I went through to the kitchen to see who was there.

2Â CUTTING/BREAKINGÂ 
cutting or breaking something, or making a hole from one side of it to the otherÂ 

A football came crashing through the window.

straight/right/clean through
The bullet passed straight through his skull.

3Â ACROSS AN AREAÂ from one side of an area to the other or between a group of thingsÂ 

We passed through France on our way to Italy.Â 
We made our way through the village to the farm.Â 
The wind howled through the trees.
He had to push his way through the crowd to get to her.Â 
Let me through â€“ Iâ€™m a doctor.
get through/make it throughÂ (=reach a place after a difficult journey)Â 
Youâ€™ll never get through â€“ the snowâ€™s two metres deep.Â 
Rescue teams have finally made it through to the survivors.Â 
We droveÂ right throughÂ the town centre.Â 
Carry onÂ straight throughÂ the village.

4Â SEE THROUGH SOMETHINGÂ if you see something through glass, a window etc, you are on one side of the glass etc and it is on the other
I could see her through the window.Â 
I couldÂ see right throughÂ the thin curtains.

5Â PAST A PLACEÂ past a place where you are https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/suppose to stopÂ 
It took us ages to get through passport control.
He droveÂ straight throughÂ a red light.

6Â TIMEÂ during and to the end of a period of timeÂ 
The cold weather continued through the spring.
He sleptÂ right throughÂ the day.
The fighting went onÂ all throughÂ the night.

7Â PROCESS/EXPERIENCEÂ from the beginning to the end of a process or experienceÂ 
The book guides you through the whole procedure of buying a house.Â 
When you have been through a terrible experience like that, it takes a long time to recover.Â 
Itâ€™s a miracle that these buildings came through the war undamaged.

8Â COMPETITIONSÂ past one stage in aÂ https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/competitionÂ to the next stage
through to
This is the first time theyâ€™ve ever made it through to the final.Â 
They didnâ€™t evenÂ get throughÂ the first round of the contest.

9Â BECAUSE OF SOMETHINGÂ because of somethingÂ 
How many working days were lost through sickness last year?

10Â BY MEANS OF SOMETHING/SOMEBODYÂ by means of a particular https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/method, service, person etc

She got her first job through an employment agency.Â 
a success that was achieved through co-operative effort and wise leadership
I heard about it through a friend.

11Â PARLIAMENT/CONGRESS
if a https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/proposal passes through aÂ https://www.ldoceonline.com/dictionary/parliament, it is agreed and accepted as a lawÂ

flashcards.title: tighten
flashcards.definition:
1 [transitive]
to close or fasten something firmly by turning it OPP loosen
Tighten the screws firmly.
Iâ€™d put the new tyre on, but I hadnâ€™t tightened up the wheel.
2 [intransitive, transitive] if you tighten a rope, wire etc, or if it tightens, it is stretch or pull so that it becomes tight
When you tighten guitar strings, the note gets higher.
The rope tightened around his body.
3 [intransitive, transitive] to become stiff or make a part of your body become stiff OPP relax
His mouth tightened into a thin, angry line.
Tighten up the muscles of both arms.
4 tighten your grip hold on something tighten your grip hold on something
a) to control a place or situation more strictly
Rebel forces have tightened their hold on the capital.
b) to hold someone or something more firmly
Sarah tightened her grip on my arm.
5 [transitive] to make a rule, law, or system more strict OPP relax
Efforts to tighten the rules have failed.
tighten up on something
a range of measures to tighten up on illegal share dealing
6 tighten your belt tighten your belt
7 tighten the screws on somebody tighten the screws on somebody
8 [intransitive] American English if a race or competition tightens, the distance between the competitor becomes smaller
He expects the presidential race to tighten.
[english)
flashcards.example:
tighten
â€¢ I think the fan belt needs to be tightened.
â€¢ The rope tightened and Steve was pulled off balance.
â€¢ Judy's lips tightened in a thin smile.
â€¢ As though to tighten it a hand came to rest on hers.
â€¢ As the investigation continued into June, Dunlap could feel the vise tighten, squeezing out any possibility of hope.
â€¢ She bent down and tightened the muzzle on the dog.
â€¢ He changed the spanner for one the correct size and tightened the nut.
â€¢ The estate owners tightened their systems, with a view to greater productivity - new breeds, crops, implements and methods.
â€¢ I felt my stomach tighten, unreason bubbling, rising.
â€¢ Tighten up the lid on that juice before you put it away.
â€¢ But Hill hurt a hamstring on the return, and had to leave the game after his leg tightened up.
â€¢ The cross-fence would be finished sometime today, once we got all the wires pulled out and tightened up.
â€¢ Tighten your stomach muscles and hold for three seconds.
tighten up on something
â€¢ Every now and then, his knees tighten up on him.
â€¢ Thus, in times of slack demand it is not uncommon to find managements tightening up on industrial discipline.
â€¢ Green wants teachers to tighten up on student attendance

flashcards.title: tiring
flashcards.definition:
making you feel that you want to sleep or rest

[english)
flashcards.example:
THESAURUS
tiring making you feel that you want to sleep or rest
The journey was really tiring.

exhausting extremely tiring

an exhausting week of singing, acting, and dancing
hard very tiring and difficult â€“ used about days, journeys etc

a hard day at work

wearing /ËˆweÉ™rÉªÅ‹ $ Ëˆwer-/ tiring because you have to use a lot of your mental energy, and often become bored â€“ used about people, situations etc

I find her constant questions rather wearing.
Kids of that age can be very wearing.
His films always tend to have the same plots, which does get rather wearing after a while.
gruelling British English, grueling American English (also punishing) very tiring physically or mentally â€“ used when you have to keep doing something for a long time
a gruelling journey across the desert
a gruelling race
a punishing schedule
a punishing exercise regime
backbreaking backbreaking work is extremely tiring and needs a lot of physical effort
Clearing the land was slow backbreaking work.
Laborers were paid $2 a day for backbreaking farm work.
something is a killer informal used when saying that something is extremely tiring
Today was a real killer.
fatiguing formal making you feel very tired

â€¢ Moving into a situation is usually less tiring than backing away.

1 for animals
a piece of equipment for catching animals

mousetrap

lay/set a trap (for somebody)

fall/walk into a trap
Mr Smith has walked straight into a trap laid by the Tories.
3 bad situation an unpleasant or difficult situation that is difficult to escape from
Amanda felt that marriage was a trap.
debt/unemployment etc trap
people caught in the unemployment trap

to turn a switch on a machine such as an oven, radio etc so that it produces more heat, sound etc OPP turn down
Turn the oven up to 220.
Turn up the radio!
2 to be found, especially by chance, after having been lost or searched for
Eventually my watch turned up in a coat pocket.
3 to arrive at a place, especially in a way that is unexpected
You canâ€™t just turn up and expect a meal.
turn up late/early/on time etc
Steve turned up late, as usual.
4 if an opportunity or situation turns up, it happens, especially when you are not expecting it
Donâ€™t worry, Iâ€™m sure a job will turn up soon.
5 turn something â†” up to find something by searching for it thoroughly
The police investigation hasnâ€™t turned up any new evidence.
6 turn something â†” up British English
to shorten a skirt, trousers etc by folding up the bottom and sewing it
[)
flashcards.example:
â€¢ Would you mind turning the heat up?
â€¢ Ben's been looking for a job for two months, but nothing good's turned up.
â€¢ I'd almost given up hope of finding a house I liked, and then suddenly this one turned up.
â€¢ After seven months on the case, the police failed to turn up any real clues.
â€¢ Hey, turn this up for a second, I like this song.
â€¢ Can you turn the television up? I can't hear it.
â€¢ A thorough examination of the company's account books turned up several interesting facts.
â€¢ Don't worry about your earrings - I'm sure they'll turn up sooner or later.
â€¢ Someone turned up the music, and people started dancing.
â€¢ We hooked up my stereo and turned up the volume as loud as it would go.
â€¢ Is the sound turned up too loud for you?
â€¢ Have those files turned up yet?

flashcards.title: twin
flashcards.definition:
Main Meanings
1. One of two children born to the same mother at the same time
â—¦ She gave birth to twins.
2. Two things that are very similar or exactly alike
â—¦ The two houses are twins.
3. (Verb) To pair or closely connect two things
â—¦ The city is twinned with Paris.
Use twice for how many times or comparison.
Use double for size, amount, or multiplication.
Use twin only for people born together or things that look very similar.

flashcards.title: twist
flashcards.definition:
1- move: to turn a part of your body around or change your position by turning
if you twist your mouth or feature, your smile in an unpleasant way or look angry
2- bend:to bend or turn something, such at wire, hair or cloth into a particular shape
3- wind: to wind something around an object
4- turn: to turn something in circle using your hand
5- road\ river: if a road river etc twists it changes direction in a series of curves
6- word: to change the true or intended meaning of a statement, especially in order to get some advantage for yourself

flashcards.title: used to thing
flashcards.definition:
"I used to think that" is correct and usable in written English. You can use this phrase to refer to something you believed in the past but no longer believe. For example, "I used to think that studying would be boring, but now I realize it can actually be quite enjoyable.".

1 SEA [countable] a line of raise water that moves across the surface of the sea

2 INCREASE [countable usually singular] a sudden increase in a particular type of behaviour, activity, or feeling

3 PEOPLE AND THINGS [countable] a sudden increase in the number of people or things arrive at the same time
wave of
a new wave of immigrants They faced wave after wave of fresh troops.
4 LIGHT AND SOUND [countable] the form in which some types of energy such as light and sound travel
sound/light/radio wave long wave long wave medium wave medium wave short wave short wave
5 SIGNAL [countable usually singular] a movement in which you raise your arm and move your hand from side to side
He dismissed her with a wave of the hand.
6 FEELING/ACTIVITY [countable] a feeling or activity that happens again and again in a series
The pain swept over him in waves.

flashcards.title: way too much
flashcards.definition:
Question: Why does "way too much" mean the same thing as "far too much"? Why does "way" mean "far" in this case?
Good question. A simple response: modern usage. Informally, one can use way (normally a noun) in place of far as an intensifier for comparatives and for â€œtoo + adjective/adverb.â€ Examples:
â€¢ She prepared way (far) too much food for our Thanksgiving meal.
â€¢ On that trip to the hospital, John drove way (far) faster than he normally does.
â€¢ Iâ€™m way (far) too tired to study for an exam this evening.
â€¢ This new washing machine is way (far) quieter than our last one.

flashcards.title: Wolf Down
flashcards.definition:
eat hastily
When you eat your breakfast as fast as possible in order to get to school on time, you can say that you wolf down your waffles.
When you engage in this kind of speed eating, you wolf down, or simply "wolf," your food. Imagine a starving wolf finally getting the chance to eat, gulping down its meal as quickly as it can before some other hungry animal comes along. Wolf down was first used in the 1860's, from this sense of "eat like a wolf."
[)
flashcards.example:
Cole wolfed down the moist piece of cake, eyeing Garvey the whole time.
The drifters had wolfed down the last morsel.

Defenition: eat hastily
When you eat your breakfast as fast as possible in order to get to school on time, you can say that youÂ wolf downÂ your waffles.
When you engage in this kind of speed eating, you wolf down, or simply "wolf," your food. Imagine a starving wolf finally getting the chance to eat, gulping down its meal as quickly as it can before some other hungry animal comes along.Â Wolf downÂ was first used in the 1860's, from this sense of "eat like a wolf."

flashcards.title: would
flashcards.definition:
1 PAST INTENTIONS/EXPECTATIONS
used to say what someone intended to do or expected to happen
They said they would meet us at 10.30 at the station.
She said she wouldnâ€™t be coming to the library anymore.
Arnold knew he would be tired the next day.
It would soon be dark.
2 IMAGINED SITUATIONS
a) used when talking about the result of a possible or imagined situation or event, or describing one
What would you do if you won a million pounds?
I would be amazed if I got the job.
It would be lovely to see you.
b) used when talking about something that did not happen, or a situation that cannot exist
I would have phoned you, but there wasnâ€™t time.
Alex would never have found out if you hadnâ€™t told him.
What would have happened if I hadnâ€™t been here?
Everything would be very different if your father were still alive.
c) used to mention an unlikely situation or event that you want to happen
I wish they would come and visit us.
If only he would listen to me.
GRAMMAR: Choosing the right tense
You usually use would in the main clause, and a past tense in the â€˜ifâ€™ clause:
I would be surprised if he agreed.
She would love it if you came.
âœ—Donâ€™t say: I would be surprised if he would agree.
3 PAST HABITS
used to say that something happened often or regularly in the past
When we worked in the same office, we would often have coffee together.
On summer evenings they would sit out in the garden.
4 REQUESTING spoken used to ask someone politely to do something
Would you shut the window, please?
Would you mind waiting outside?
Would someone please tell me what is going on?
5 OFFERING/INVITING spoken used to offer something to someone or invite them somewhere politely
Would you like a coffee?
Weâ€™re going to the theatre this evening. Would you be interested in coming?
6 WHAT SOMEBODY WANTS spoken used to say that someone wants something or wants to do something
would like/love/prefer
Yes, please, Iâ€™d love a coffee.
My parents would like to meet you.
Claudia would have liked to refuse (=wanted to refuse), but she didnâ€™t dare.
Iâ€™d hate (=I do not want) to disappoint you.
would rather/sooner (=used to say what someone prefers)
Iâ€™d rather stay in this evening, if thatâ€™s all right with you.
7 PAST PURPOSE used after â€˜so thatâ€™ to show that someone was trying to make something happen or prevent something
We packed all the books in wooden boxes so that they wouldnâ€™t get damaged.
8 would not
9 ADVICE spoken used when giving or asking for advice
Iâ€™d try to get there early if you can.
I would talk to the doctor if I were you.
What would you do if you were in my position?
10 I would think/imagine/say
11 TYPICAL BEHAVIOUR spoken used to say that an action is typical or expected â€“ usually used to show disapproval
You would go and spoil it, wouldnâ€™t you!
She insists that she did nothing wrong, but then she would say that, wouldnâ€™t she?
12 would that â€¦
